Évaluation publiée le 30 avril 2017
I really wanted to like this game. There are a lot of cool concepts and gadgets that you get as the game progresses, but I found myself wondering when the tutorial was going to end. About an hour in, I realized that this was the game. Unfortunately, the puzzles are very discrete - they never really build off of each other. And they are so simple. I spent more time handling the glitches and poor game mechanics than I did actually thinking about how to solve the puzzles. I think that if you go in wanting a quick, fun game on a rainy afternoon, this may be a contender. But at $20, I think that you can find ones much more satisfying than this one.
 
charly
0
4 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
5.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 3 novembre 2021
Quadrilateral Cowboy is a first-person puzzle adventure game set in a retro cyberpunk world. You play as a hacker whose job is to successfully pull off heists with the array of high-tech gadgets at your disposal. The most important being your ‘hacking deck’, a laptop that allows you to execute commands via a simplified pseudo-code to unlock doors, control remote controlled dog robots, as well as shoot remote sentry turrets. Quadrilateral Cowboy is wonderfully unique and innovative in its aesthetic and gameplay, however, it also has many faults and falls short of its full potential.

First, lets start with the good. The story of Quadrilateral Cowboy has very little in the way of actual plot and is instead presented solely through environmental storytelling and atmosphere. The game follows the exploits of a 3 women team who utilise their engineering and IT skills to perfect heists in virtual reality before enacting their plans. In-between missions you get a glimpse into their personal lives as well as the dystopic world they live in. It is short, simple and effective.

The gameplay is similarly simple and effective, with the first five missions in particular being well designed and paced. Each mission has three jobs in the same setting but with a different objective each and varying in puzzle difficulty. The first mission eases you into the basics by introducing you to the hacking deck, and with each job requiring a little more complicated coding each time. The second mission introduces the remote controlled robot dog, and again like any good puzzle game, gives you a simple problem to begin with to learn and then tests you with puzzles that require you to apply what you have learned in creative ways. And the game holds this pattern of introducing a new gadget and then giving you a three job tutorial to play and understand it for the next three missions with the jump pad, remote controlled gun, as well as a unique remote code execution blink system. And this first half of the game is great, it’s innovative in its mechanics, the difficulty curve of the puzzles is just right, and it’s introducing new gadgets every chapter.

But then the game just kind of switches gears. The sixth mission is a tutorial for a group heist, which sounds cool on paper but in practice just isn’t that challenging or interesting. The seventh mission is the first proper group heist where you mostly just walk forward and interact with what you have the prompt to interact for and that’s kind of it. You don’t use any of the gadgets you used before and now chapters are just one mission instead of containing three different jobs. In the eighth mission, the only gadget you use is the jump pad. The ninth mission you get to use the deck and the remote controlled gun, but its very simple and short. The tenth and final mission is a return to form, requiring you to use every gadget at your disposal and tests everything you have learned during the course of the game, but at this stage in the game it’s too little too late.

So in summary, the first five levels – which is essentially the tutorial - is great. The gameplay mechanics are unique, innovative and interesting, the level design and puzzle design is good and the difficulty curve is just right for a tutorial. But then it goes completely off on a tangent and leaves you with only the last level as the deepest exploration of the games mechanics. There are no late game puzzles that really test your understanding and mastery of the gadgets like there would be in any other complete puzzle game. This has left a bad taste in many peoples mouths because what the game is doing has potential, but it falls far short of this potential. Many people wonder when they are going to leave the tutorial and enter the game proper only to be met with the end credits. It would be like if Portal or Portal 2 only contained the first handful of tutorial chambers and that was it. I do also need to mention that this game is rife with bugs and has crashed several times for me in my 4 hours of play time.

As it stands, Quadrilateral Cowboy is an interesting experiment. The use of pseudo-code and gadgets are awesome, the environmental storytelling is lovely, and the puzzles are well designed and paced, which is enough of a reason to play this game. But there is no shaking that this feels like a proof of concept or rather just the tutorial for a larger game that doesn’t exist. I recommend this game to anyone looking for a unique and interesting puzzle game with style, but with the caveat that it is short and leaves much of its potential unfulfilled, so try to keep that in mind and I think you will enjoy what is there. Finally, it pains me to say this about an indie game, but you should really only buy this game on sale, Quadrilateral Cowboy is no where near as complete and polished as even other indie games at this price point.
 
Aps

29 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile

0
Non recommandé
14.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 28 juillet 2016
其实我非常喜欢这款游戏，但这是因为我是编程游戏的脑残粉，
对于对编程类游戏、cyberpunk题材都不感冒的普通steam玩家来说，
这款游戏你可能会觉得内容太少太无聊，而且玩的不明所以，
考虑到评分对玩家的导向，所以我不向你推荐这款游戏，但我对这款游戏是给好评的

================= 正文 =================

一款cyberpunk风格，比较意识流的解谜游戏（不是潜行游戏）

画面是简陋了点，不过如果你是画面党，看到截图直接就CTRL+W了，也就不会来看评测了吧

刚开始以为是一款像人力资源机器、TIS-100、uplink之类的游戏，
然而实际上并不是，游戏中几乎没有深入编程、黑客之类的元素，完全不涉及算法，
也没有简介和宣传片截图中那样看起来的硬件电路设计，
游戏只是以函数调用和命令行的方式让你控制一些物品和开关而已，非常简单。
电脑的存在感在开头机关之后就逐渐下降了，
更多的是机器狗、机枪、和风扇跳板（让我想起了塔罗斯的法则）

这些谜题几乎没有难度，但每个谜题思路都不同，失败重试也很方便，
谜题和剧情互相推动产生变化，也不会让你觉得无聊

游戏的方式主要就是
1：查看地图了解目标和机关
2：运用道具解决谜题，主要是电脑、TV、机器狗、机枪、和风扇跳板。电脑中的命令行可以控制机器狗和机枪，你自己摸不到的机关都要通过这两者来控制。TV给你提供这两者的视野。风扇跳板用来位移，有些任务是限时触发警报的，只是增加了操作难度而已。
3：目标各不相同，有盗取公文包、偷保险箱、下载大脑信息。
4：回到出发点

每做完一个大任务，就有段小插曲，只是让你可以走剧情，没有谜题。

游戏剧情还是蛮有趣的，没有旁白没有说明，全都靠你自己理解，
大体上是扮演一个三个妹子组成的犯罪团体进行违法活动的故事。

Pros:
+ cyberpunk题材背景设定，编程黑客元素
+ 看得出是花了心思在设计谜题，而不是靠PCG堆砌同样解题思路的谜题
+ 游戏指导非常详细
+ 耐人寻味的剧情
+ 悠闲放松的游戏体验（有好友排行榜和世界平均，但对游戏完全没有影响）

♥♥♥♥:
- 流程较短
- 画面简陋
- 谜题设计和剧情上都缺乏深入，不能尽兴（没有任何挫折障碍，缺乏解决谜题、通关等的快感）
 
UnluckyNinja
1
4 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé

Évaluation publiée le 31 juillet 2016
Really enjoyed this game. Incredibly charming, with fun tools that continually expand the possibility space. The environments that the "heists" take place in are imaginative and clever. My only significant complaints are that I wish the whole toolset had been used in more missions once you have access to it, and I wish there had been more multi team member missions. That said, better to end strong than overstay your welcome.

Since the game has built in mod support, there is reason to hope that the community might take that ball and run with it. Regardless, I think it was well worth the money, just make sure you are ok with a reasonably significant amount of typing!

Évaluation publiée le 25 juillet 2016
I've been anticipating this game for the past couple of years and I can definitely say the wait has been worth it. An immersive hacking interface, fun spy gadgets, and a very curious setting indeed! The feeling of solving a puzzle with a flow of commands and quick thinking is quite a fun rush, and with Workshop support I look forward to seeing players' custom maps and other fun things like that!

If you're a fan of hacking/typing games that allow you to manipulate the world through coding and commands (See also ComputerCraft for Minecraft, and Wiremod in Garry's Mod), I definitely recommend this!
 
Varius
1,293 produits enregistrés
0
4 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
3.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 28 juillet 2016
This is an excellent hand-crafted puzzle game with beautiful story moments and gorgeous details. Like the rest of the Blendo Games first person catalog, it never wastes your time -- every room of every level is about something, there's no "filler" here. Imagine the purity and confidence of Portal 1 (a puzzle game that gracefully knew when to stop) with the visual sensibilities of Hong Kong filmmaker Wong Kar-wai, and you get QuadCow.

Many of the negative reviews here are going to complain about how the game doesn't escalate into a hugely over-complicated multi-part multi-agent mission that requires you to engineer 100s of lines of code with 20 different remote devices... but I think it was a wise decision to avoid this same trap that nearly every coding puzzle game falls into.

This is not a programming game about complexity -- rather, it's about ingenuity.

This is not about designing a giant system with 100 moving parts, and Portal would not have been a better game with 8 portals. Instead, this game is about using the right command at the right time at the right place. (If you know what you're doing, you can complete many of the levels in 30-60 seconds. But the first time you try, it'll take you 15-30 minutes.)

Conceptually, QuadCow is about re-imagining the act of coding. Is coding a slow crawl of engineering, or can it be a light and delicate performance, like cold water or a kiss?

If you want TIS-100, go play TIS-100. But in this game, YOU ARE A COWBOY, NOT AN ASSEMBLY PROGRAMMER. It's in the gosh-darn title, ok???

(Disclosure: I alpha-tested this game and bought the game myself.)
 
Radiatoryang
0
6 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
22.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 1 aout 2017
I love this game, but I should note it is short. About 6 hours of my game play were on the story line in the game, the other 3.9 hours were in community made maps. This game feels like an advanced portal in the terms of game mechanics. There's just so many different challenges you can make with these mechanics that map builders have infinite map designs. I should note that creating a map may be difficult for people new to map building, but those with experience might be able to catch on immediately.

The only thing this game needs is a larger community workshop base, and it would be 10/10.

Blendo games have widely varying degrees of gameplay and story. Quadrilateral Cowboy strikes the perfect balance for me. My biggest complaint is that there isn't more. There could easily be more challenge added to the existing content with a hard mode, 3 job marathon, the mind races.

Workshop support is great but sadly underutilized. Also, there are some minor bugs and glitches.

Overall: well worth a try, a great way to spend an afternoon.

5.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 19 mai 2019
I wouldn't say this is a hacking/thief simulator as there isn't much of a world built around the levels. But it does stand up as a decent puzzle game that will make you think for more than a second.

The story is ambiguous to the point you can use a fair bit of your imagination to interpret what is going on. However, that ambiguity doesn’t detract from the heist based puzzles that are a treat to figure out, during each and every level.

My big gripe (like most people), is that the game is very short and ends fairly abruptly. Unfortunately, it would have been nice if everything you learnt was culminated in the use of one big level at the end. Never the less, had loads of fun and still well worth it on sale, $28.95AUD is a bit much though.

Recommandé
6.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 2 décembre 2019
After finishing this game, I'm mad. I love it, but I can't recommend it for full price.
Mechanically it's incredibly solid, and the aesthetics have a lot of potential, but it ends up feeling more like a long demo than a full game. There is no third act where every skill comes together, with most of the stages being tutorials, yet some mechanics just show up at the end with no explanation, as if the devs finished them and were like "Oh well just throw them in, we dont have time to make more levels for them). It's also terribly glitched at times, particularly with the physics, and I was forced to restart the stage a couple of times.
I would love to see a sequel with more levels and a much much better story. As it is, its worth getting it for 5 bucks, 10 at most, if you're into programming and planning, but I really hope we get to see more done with it in the future.

0
15 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation amusante
0
Non recommandé
3.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 2 janvier 2019
It's hard to decide whether to recommend this game. Ultimately I have to say no, though I fully believe many will love it, but in the end I put it down.

First thing I should caveat this with is I'm REALLY not a fan of the Blendo games' style. I think the blocky, low-poly visuals and washed-out, muted colors look really awful, and I just don't buy the idea that a game can look "good" by deliberately trying to look dated visually. I'm not a ♥♥♥♥♥ for presentation, but a nice presentation goes a long way to make up for shortcomings elsewhere in a game. Here, the terrible graphics and limited use of sound are only a detriment.

The actual gameplay is where this game shines, and is at odds with the game's design at almost every turn. The idea is you pull off heists by interacting with the world via a simple computer interface, where you code command lines to switch off lasers, open doors, aim guns, etc. This felt wholly original and unique to me and for a while I was having a LOT of fun with it. Even the clunkiness honestly adds to the experience (for example, lots of trial error in determining how far to zoom in, where to aim a gun, things like this). But it adds to the experience because it feels like you're actually programming and solving problems via this computer interface. It's cool.

I just wish this concept was put into a better GAME. The design decisions in Quadrilateral Cowboy are baffling. Aside from the whole game feeling like a tech demo, here are some of the annoyances I had in the couple hours I've played:

1. Lots of levels have intant-fail conditions that take you back to the beginning if you're not extremely careful at every step. In some sense these can add to it too (like needing to open a window before shooting a bullet through it or an alarm will go off, or planning out how to escape a room in 10 seconds knowing an alarm is going to go off soon). But the fact that the levels have no checkpoints meants you'll be going back to the beginning sometimes only to slug your way through the same 90% you've already done just to get the timing of that last 10% down right. It's annoying.

2. The game doesn't build. It introduces new mechanics and then quickly forgets about them more often than not.

3. The jumping mechanic is ridiculous. There was one level where I was stuck for a while because I couldn't figure out how to progress, only to realize I needed to jump onto a platform that's like 20 feet high (apparently the main character can jump REALLY high for no clear reason). But the need to jump in that level made absolutely no sense in terms of design - it wasn't a platforming segment, there was no challenge involved, there was just one very specific moment where you had to jump once and that's it. Very strange.

4. There's a story, but it's doled out in short, weird, obtuse bits that make very little sense on their own, and I quickly lost interest trying to piece it together. I also absolutely hated Thirty Flights of Loving and thought it was a complete waste of money, so take that for what it's worth, because the storytelling here is similar.

Overall, I just wish a developer would take this concept and polish it into a game that's more worth playing, with a better presentation, more cohesive design and mechanics that actually build on one another and introduce themselves at a pace that makes sense. What's here now is worth trying if you can get it on sale, but otherwise it's hard to recommend.
 
michaelzee1
0
3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
9.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 25 décembre 2018
Игра рассказывает историю трёх подруг, которые занимаются опасным делом - проникновением со взломом во всех смыслах.
Вооруженные последними технологиями, (компьютерная дека с 256кб оперативы, робот на ножках, радиоуправляемая снайперская винтовка и др.) девчонки выполняют поручения корпораций.
Игра очень разнообразна в плане геймплея и многие уровни можно пройти используя несколько методов. Можете неторопливо доставать деку возле каждой системы, чтобы производить взлом на месте. А можете изучить строение уровня, чтобы написать целую программу, которая будет точно по таймингу активировать нужные двери и рычаги, чтобы вы беспрепятственно скользили по уровню. Каждую миссию открывается новый гаджет, так что заскучать вряд ли получится.
В игре нет диалогов и весь сюжет подается через окружение. Рабочее место хакеров, их личные вещи, документы и фотографии рассказывают довольно подробную историю их жизни. А все геймплейные механики объясняются через буклеты с инструкциями и этикетками на оборудовании. Например, на решетке с жирнющими прутьями будет этикетка производителя и их слоган "НЕ ОТКРОЕТСЯ НИКОГДА". И она действительно не откроется.
Еще в игре есть таблицы лидеров, чтобы флексить перед друзьями. И система записок а-ля Dark Souls, с помощью которой можно оставлять подсказки.
Короче, купите эту пeздaтую игру. Брендон Чанг (разработчик) толкает гейминг вперед на своём горбу в полном одиночестве. И ну очень надо поддержать.
 
Dick Cheeser
644 produits enregistrés
0
9 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
11.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 14 mai 2017
Great game. Unique spin on the familiar cyberpunk genre. Setting and characters are endearing and memorable despite the lack of dialogue. Level design is tight and communicative. Puzzles are interesting, but not longer or more complex than they need to be. I did feel like the game could have used one more BIG mission, with multiple paths all tying together the various techniques and gadgets you've aquired throughout the game, but in the end I'm always happier to be left wanting more than to have a game full of filler to grind through.
 
Racketmensch

I love this game! I really enjoy the way they told the story. It just kind of lays it out in front of you without beating you over the head with it or explaining it to you.
The gameplay was great! easy enough to figure out, but complicated enough that it felt a bit open worldish.
Encountered 0 glitches, the whole experience felt very smooth!

I would recommend getting it on sale due to the fact I got 100% completion in about 6 hours, and I don't see much replay value in it once you figure out the puzzles.

Évaluation publiée le 16 octobre 2016
Pro:
  • interessanter Grafikstil
  • tolle und neuartige Spielmechaniken
  • komplett abgedrehte Welt
  • nette Nebenmissionen
  • man kann alle Missionsziele in einem Durchgang erfüllen oder einfach nach einander
  • Programmieren super einfach gemacht
♥♥♥:
  • Steuerung manchmal etwas schwierig: man wirft ausversehen schnell mal etwas durch den Raum und der Alarm geht los, weil man etwas kaputt gemacht hat
  • Interface teilweise sehr nervig, vor allem Flimmereffekte
  • für fast 20€ ein sehr stolzer Preis
Fazit:
Tolles Spiel, lohnt sich auf jeden Fall zu spielen, 20€ sind jedoch viel zu teuer. Am Besten ihr holt euch das spiel einfach im Sale.

Recommandé
3.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 6 aout 2016
Produit reçu gratuitement

Το Quadrilateral Cowboy δεν αποτελεί σε καμία περίπτωση την αποκάλυψη για την οποία κόπτονται αρκετοί συνάδελφοι του χώρου. Είναι έξυπνο, ατμοσφαιρικό και αυτοσαρκαστικό. Το γνώριμο πνεύμα του Chung βρίσκεται σε κάθε pixel του και αρκετές φορές θα σας κάνει να νιώσετε ως σπουδαίοι “cowboys” του κυβερνοχώρου. Η πλήρης έλλειψη διαλόγων ή κάποιας ιστορίας με συνοχή όμως, σε συνδυασμό με τα bugs και το αρκετά περιορισμένο περιεχόμενο, το καθιστούν περισσότερο μια όμορφη πλατφόρμα με πολλές δυνατότητες για επίδοξους προγραμματιστές παρά ένα ολοκληρωμένο παιχνίδι που προορίζεται για μαζική επιτυχία.

Εάν είστε θιασώτες της «προγραμματιστικής» σκέψης και των puzzle games, θα περάσετε δυο όμορφα απογεύματα με το Quadrilateral Cowboy. Η ατμόσφαιρά του παραμένει το δυνατότερο χαρτί του και είναι κρίμα να βρίσκεται σε δεύτερο πλάνο, πίσω από απλές ασκήσεις συγχρονισμού και λογικής.

Διαβάστε περισσότερα στο www.ragequit.gr
 
Rivereyes
1,149 produits enregistrés

Recommandé
5.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 11 novembre 2018
It's cyberpunk-hacking-heist game set in the far future of 1980s. You sneak around vents, find terminals to hack doors with your top-of-the-line, 256k RAM, 64k ROM, 10 Mhz clock microprocessor, hacking deck (I know, it's quite overpowered just to hack some doors or camera), steal the top secret diskette, then get the hell away from Dodge. It's cute, the world is full of details that you'd miss if you just mindless run and do all the missions, and is super good.

Gameplay is smooth as jazz, make you feel like you're an actual hacker, doing an actual heist, but what also amazed me is all the style dripping from the lo-fi graphic. The graphic is not fancy, but it's just chock full of subtle details and humours and style and doesn't feel like blocks bought from asset stores because the creator can't do any better (the point is, it might! but the dev definitely know how to make it like it doesn't! This really show the difference between good and bad designer).
 
fri_freeman

5 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile

Recommandé
5.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 1 aout 2016
我已经关注这个游戏有一段时间了，当年看预告的时候就感觉这个游戏很有碟中谍+黑客帝国+银翼杀手的感觉，实际上也确实有，而且那种通过打代码黑进系统的感觉很带感。尽管这个游戏确实有很多亮点，然而不得不说，就目前游戏的状态来看，并不是非常建议全价购买。最大的问题在于关卡实在是太少了，大概4~5个小时就能搞定，而且除了最后一关还算是有点难度而且利用上所有的机制之外，谜题都不算困难。潜力是有的，尤其是利用各种类型解谜用的道具其实完全可以把关卡做的更复杂一些，如果加入创意工坊或者作者自己再多加一些关卡会更耐玩一些，然而就目前的状态来看，唯一的重复可玩性就在于刷最快时间了。

不管怎么说，游戏本身的创意和氛围还有那个迷之故事主线都属于上乘水准，内容的缺失也的的确确是硬伤，有兴趣的朋友推荐打折的时候买一个玩玩吧，或者玩玩塔罗斯法则什么的……

7/10
 
Gene Mono,

7 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile

Recommandé
4.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 25 juillet 2016
TLDR:
How long to complete:
If you rush through it all, you can probably complete it in under 4 hours.

Great style, references to the genre aplenty, explore, solve puzzles and throw in some terminal style typing to control/hack your environment.

9/10 - If it had an 80's mix of electronica in the soundtrack it would have been epic.

Extras:
Developer Commentary is a great touch to check out after completing the game.
Credits are unique and fit the game's style spot on.
Modding - It should be interesting what the community and/or Blendo releases in the future!

Extended:

First of all.. It’s a straight up puzzle solving game with STAGES.
Then it's a command-via-typing / exploration style game.
For those wondering: I'd say it's 50/50 with typing and exploring - Some more than others at times.

Instead of interacting with things point blank, you enter commands on your "mobile" terminal, control robots, fire weapons, use jump pads and more! Feels like pieces of other titles meshed together with a unique art style in the process of being perfected by Blendo.

After the first portion of the solo play it splits into a multi-mode where you case, engineer and grease your way through stages. The trick being the actions you do in time affect the next mode you play. It's a fun twist and change to the first portion.

Without ruining too much of the puzzle aspect of the game, the stages have been very thought out and the more items you unlock, the harder things get.

Be prepared to restart stages to achieve the fastest times without penalties.

Say hello to Chu Chu the black-market cat.
 
snarkydonald
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
4.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 29 avril 2019
Quadrilateral Cowboy is one of those rare games where you can feel the heart the creator put into it. The game is flawed and lacks polish- I died or got stuck occasionally when I got thrown through a wall, the game crashed to desktop multiple times around the midway point (not too much of an issue as the game autosaves after every level but still annoying), and the last level is an incredibly steep difficulty spike compared to the rest of the game. Despite all this, the core mechanics are well thought out and implemented, getting you to really feel like you're a super spy. The game's ambiance is also fantastic, painting a picture of a distopian, retrofuturistic 1980 that draws heavily on steampunk aesthetics and early 20th century science fiction. Quadrilateral Cowboy is a very human experience that happens to have a reasonably good puzzle game attached to in- while I probably wouldn't buy it for the full price 20$, this would be at the top of my list of games to get while on sale

Évaluation publiée le 23 octobre 2018
This game is freaking amazing, a bit short unforchantely. It only took me about 10 hours to complete the game but every second was enjoyable. The puzzles seem daunting at first but the satifisfaction of solving them is worth it. They certainly were fun, getting my brain to work hard piecing everything together. It was a relaxing experiecnce for me to play this game listening to its soothing soundtrack as I solved its puzzles. The ending made me a bit sad wanting more puzzles and for the game not to end. If you like puzzle games and hacking then this game is exactly for you. I would highly recommend it to anyone that seems interested.

9.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 13 novembre 2020
Un juego bastante genuino en su mecánica y estilo.

Se puede decir que es una experiencia breve, pero muy bien lograda donde formamos parte de un grupo que tiene como objetivo cometer robos de información a través de contratos, cada uno de estos lo hacemos ♥♥♥ diversos dispositivos electrónicos que aprendemos a manipular desde el inicio ♥♥♥ comandos para cada uno, empezando ♥♥♥ tareas simples como abrir puertas hasta llegar a tener que combinar muchas acciones entre los mismos dependiendo del entorno.

La dificultad está relacionada directamente a como se te ocurra conseguirlo, cada dispositivo se tiene que desplegar físicamente teniendo cada uno sus funciones, peso y interactividad ♥♥♥ lo que tengan cerca, ésto sumado a la cantidad de variaciones tienen los comandos, te dejan buena cantidad de opciones para realizar cada tarea.

Se puede resumir en un juego corto de duración, pero ♥♥♥ una estética muy cuidada en cada detalle y una mecánica que engancha una vez que vas dominando las cosas que el juego te enseña progresivamente.
Recomendable si te interesa sentir que estás haciendo hackeos a bajo costo.

Non recommandé
3.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 10 janvier 2017
TL;DR the game feels half done.

The mechanics are great and make for interesting puzzles but don't always expand on the concepts: the first half of the game pretty thoroughly explores the use of your deck (which is more command line interface than programming), but the second half seems to only scratch the surface of the multiple heister possibilities before giving you all the abilities on one character anyways. Multiple weevers, or using the weever and autocase simultaneously, are never explored even though the tools and commands hint at the possibility. Workshop support really SHOULD make up for some of these flaws, but six months later only a handful of levels even exist.

The plot and backstory stuff feels like it's building up to something big, but it never gets there which is unusual given the developer's past works. The game does a good job of establishing the basics of who these people you're playing as are in between levels, but there's never a moment where these relationships are tested or a true antagonist emerges. Some really cool things happen, and then they just stop happening. Apparently you're playing the first two years of a 15+ year career before flashing forward to old age in the epilogue, where they show off all the equipment you would've gotten. SUCH a tease...

On a technical level the game runs fine, but a couple of level breaking bugs forced me to close and reopen the game in order to reattempt the level.


After the reputation built up from Gravity Bone and Thirty Flights of Loving, I was just expecting more than the game gave me. If you're a puzzle fanatic and just want to tool around with some interesting mechanics, then by all means go for it. If you're expecting this to grab your attention in any other way, move on.


 
Largahblarga
637 produits enregistrés
0
3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
6.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 22 février 2020
Quadrilateral Cowboy is a really interesting and cool game. It's billed as a 'hacking' game, but I would call that a misnomer; it's more like an infiltration and heist puzzle game. (Of course, one might say that infiltration is "hacking a location"? But while you do type a few console commands, that part of the game is very simple.)

Gameplay is, basically, performing a series of heists. (Technically the conceit is that you're "planning" the heists, but whatever.) You have to explore the levels and figure out what switches to press, or what commands to send to dataports in order to get to your objective. As you go through the game, you get introduced to more and more tools, and things can ultimately get rather complex. The gameplay is fascinating, and the really good thing is that it doesn't require much in the way of reflexes or manual dexterity. (I did have to play through the last level about half a dozen times, but it didn't get too frustrating.)

Another really great thing about Quadrilateral Cowboy is its aesthetic. It's billed as "twentieth-century cyberpunk", and it seems to take place in an alternate world where twentieth-century technology is put to information age uses. This is a world where you can run heists on a cable car speeding through the night, where a space elevator has a "Please return breathing equipment here" door, where your character uses a "Vinylman" portable record player with headphones. It's fascinating and charming.

Speaking of charming, one really interesting feature of the game is the cutscenes between the levels. They're understated vignettes that give you glimpses into the characters' lives. I don't want to spoil much, but even though these scenes were short, I really enjoyed them.

All in all, I enjoyed my time with Quadrilateral Cowboy.
 
Cultist John
1,472 produits enregistrés
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
4.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 6 novembre 2019
Pleasant Puzzler with a slight programming twist. Do not let the reliance on the tech scare you away, it really is more about cramming your ideas into a given format. If you're in to the idea of planning a heist and love games that require some planning, this is for you.

The story is both light and heavy, at the same time. A glimpse into a section of life for a group of friends, how they achieved something great, and the joy that nostalgia can bring.

I question the $20 price point given the content length, but when on sale for $10'ish, I highly recommend.

Recommandé
7.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 28 novembre 2017
Do you like the old heist capers? Do you adore Jazzpunk? Do you love production design and animation where you pore over every object and want to zoom into details of the world? Well, this decidedly 20th century take on cyberpunk with an all-female heist team should be up your alley. You play as Poncho the hacker in the funniest, quirkiest, and most varied game of 2016. The new mechanics keep on coming to the very end. Each time you type out the commands to increasingly complex steps to complete your heist in success, it's super satisfying. More than that though, is the character building through intimate moments such as finding Poncho waking up after a one night stand or playing badminton with her friend that really give this a heartwarming touch.

5.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 20 avril 2021
One of the best indie games that I've ever played. Most indie games fail to reach even half the caliber of Quadrilateral Cowboy.

- The atmosphere, music, and art style are stylized and original.
- Unique mechanics in every single level, no gameplay element is overused or underused.
- A true puzzle game that rewards the player with numerous "aha!" moments without being too difficult or too easy,

Just play it and support the developer. He is one of the few devs that still strives for originality and genre-invention.

Évaluation publiée le 12 aout 2016
While it's a bit short, it's easily one of the most unique and interesting puzzle games and hacking games I've ever played. The style is bold and strange, but appealing at the same time, and the puzzles are all very well-designed, with most of them really making you feel like you're infiltrating some sort of high-security base just with your laptop and a few other little gadgets. With the added mod support, I'd say this game is easily worth the money.

30.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 25 mars 2017
A simply amazing game. I was just pulled in. This game is a master piece. I can go on and on about how I love this game. The game play feels good, and it feels like you're hacking stuff, controlling robots and guns with just console cammands, but it's not overly complicated like in real life. So anyone can play without having to have to much skill. The lighting was amazing, best light in a video game ever, and it runs on and engine from 2004 was mind blowning. I didn't think you could make such great physics from an engine that old. The story is great too, a story told with no words, but full of emotion. You feel so trusting in your two friends right away. This game is a master piece and is just so perfect. I only have one problem with the game, that is that I wish there was more. I would like to see a sequel to this. Besides that this game is amazing and you should buy it now.

2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
3.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 3 décembre 2021
Really nice puzzle game. I really like the idea of using different gadgets to plan and execute heists, but it still feels like this game didn't explore the level creation possibilities it presents. It's kinda like the game tries to do something new for a single level and then gives up on the idea, such as when it introduces the idea of "time travel" team play with multiple characters and then in the next level merges both characters into one, effectively throwing the concept away.
The game ends on a level that should have been the first of a set of more complex/difficult levels, as it's the point in the game where you have all the gadgets, so the game should have allowed you to use them creatively.
Still, it's a nice game and you can always play custom workshop levels to complement your campaign experience.
 
jvbf
333 produits enregistrés
0
3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
5.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 28 juillet 2016
A fantastic experience, albeit a short one. While the other reviewers are correct in that the game ends before it truly begins, the core mechanics are solid. It is clear that the fine folks at Blendo have assembled a fantastic set of building blocks, they simply need to do some more building with them.

As I said, the mechanics are solid. Using the deck to interact with both items in the level and subsequent tech feels fantastic. The alarm timers are a nice solution to the problem of giving the user too much direct control - if a door or laser is opened for more than a (visibly posted) length of time, an alarm sounds. This prevents the user from simply holding doors open indefinitely and lends itself also to some of the more interesting timing puzzles.

In short, while I hope more content is forthcoming, I consider Quadrilateral Cowboy as it stands worthy of the price of admission.
 
KrunkSplein
1,362 produits enregistrés
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
12.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 4 janvier 2022
De los mejores juegos que he jugado en mi vida, podría decir que hasta obra maestra. Un gran juego que puedo recomendar abiertamente a cualquier persona. El único "pero" que pondría es que dura como 4 horas y por el precio, se les puede hacer caro a muchos, aunque hay niveles de la comunidad que son de hecho, bastante buenos y posiblemente de los mejores niveles fan-made que he probado en cualquier comunidad de videojuegos.

Nunca creí que un juego donde escribes código sería tan divertido

un poco de detalle

Todos los apartados en este juego son excelentes. Destaco la banda sonora que consiste en una selección de las primeras canciones grabadas, casi toda música de 1910-1920. Creo que la única excepción es la versión de Clair de Lune que usa el juego, esa es algo más contemporánea.
El arte si bien es muy simple, creo que es exactamente lo que el juego necesita y le va muy bien, todos los diseños encajan ♥♥♥ gameplay y estética.

El gameplay y el tipo de puzzles son simplemente fenomenales. Cada nivel es algo nuevo, cada que aprendes algo hay algo nuevo que aprender y todo evoluciona de una manera que no te esperas pero se siente muy natural. Creo que una comparación apropiada es Portal, pero mucho más alocado al disponer de muchísimas más herramientas y opciones. la verdad es que al inicio es un poco raro y difícil de entender, el primer nivel confunde algo, pero una vez lo superas, ya estás listo para lo que sigue y el juego va como la mantequilla.
El diseño de niveles también es muy chulo y es todavía más chulo que muchas misiones puedas cumplir todos los objetivos seguidos y de golpe, sin el orden que se te indica. Todo depende de cómo quieras hacerlo y de si logras diseñar un plan y ejecutarlo correctamente.

La narrativa me encanta porque es super sútil y es 0 texto. La verdad es que cuando jugue esto, ya estaba algo harto de los AAA y sus 40 cutscenes para hacer cualquier cosa, entonces un juego que del minuto 00:20 te deja jugar hasta el final, es una bendición. Igual ♥♥♥ la historia, si te quieres enterar te toca fijarte en los detalles e hilar los hilos, si no, puedes jugar sin quién te detenga.
Destaco la energía ♥♥♥ la que se presenta cada nuevo escenario, personaje u objeto, las transiciones entre nivel y nivel. Las secciones en las que puedes ver a los personajes en su entorno más normal conviviendo. Todo parece no decir tanto, pero realmente ♥♥♥ detenerte poco, entiendes bastante. Verdaderamente me encanta la presentación de todo en este juego y la manera en la que cuenta su historia.

ambientación
Quiero destacar que la review negativa más popular ataca la estética y ambientación del juego porque afirma que "el juego es de los más confusos porque mezcla muchas épocas". Honestamente me parece lamentable esta declaración, ya que me parece un insulto a la creatividad. Es como decir que todas las cosas se tienen que hacer dentro de moldes que ya se han hecho y no puedes crear nada distinto.
A mí me parece fantástico que los artistas simplemente creen su mundo ♥♥♥ lo que les gusta y ya. Así se hace en quadrilateral y me parece hermoso poder encontrarse ♥♥♥ cosas así. Que simplemente puedan meter arquitectura de los 60s y de los 20s junta, ♥♥♥ reproductores de casette (excepto que son de vinilo), ♥♥♥ elementos cyberpunk, que hayan libros de los 30s-50s, que el diseño d interiores haya mezclas de 50s y 70s, haya dirigibles, encima también andes en el espacio y sea como un futuro muy lejano, pero está ubicado en los 80s. No sé ustedes, pero es maravilloso que alguien pueda mezclar todas estas cosas que le gustan para crear su ficción y darle un toque super único a su obra.

Online?
El juego tiene unas funciones super extrañas pero super chulas. Posees postits para escribir y pegar notas donde quieras dentro de un nivel. La gracia de esas notas es que las pueden ver tus amigos que también poseen el juego y quedan como si estuviesen firmadas por ti ♥♥♥ tu username de Steam. Es algo tontísimo pero a mí me hacía mucha gracia ver las notas ocultas que dejaba un amigo. Algunas notas eran memes, otras consejos y en otras contaba algo random.
La otra cosa es que puedes ver el tiempo en el que completan tus amigos un nivel, aunque siendo honestos, no es para nada tan chulo como las notas.

Definitivamente un juego que merece muchísima más atención de la que ha tenido
 
El Metan
174 produits enregistrés

Break into everything. Steal everything. Get obliterated by blimps with comically large dynamite suppression tactics. Plan everything and watch it all crumble apart because you sneezed wrong with the Weever and broke some glass window.

This game is everything I've wanted. Little bit of hacking, a lot of trying to figure out what everything does and failing miserably in the process all while the game's story is the most nonsensical, simplistic crap you could imagine.

You really should play it.

Évaluation publiée le 11 janvier 2019
Quadrilateral Cowboy — это блюз эпохи Жюля Верна и французских фильмов 70-х. Ретростилистика и головоломки на скриптинг в шпионской истории про девчонок хакеров, которые хотели изменить свои жизни. Помимо узнаваемого визуального стиля, балансирующего на грани модного и уродливого, авторы Gravity Bone и Thirty Flights of Loving специализируются на ретро-шпионском антураже, непредсказуемых шутках, экстравагантном подборе саундтреков и искусстве «монтажа» в духе кинематографа, когда «нарезка» кадров скачет перед глазами не в роликах, а прямо во время миссии.
Умные, взрослые и необычные игры в кураторской группе The Clever Gamer
 
tomasribakov

4 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
5.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 26 juillet 2016
Quadrilateral Cowboy is a clever puzzle game about space and the world around you, told through hacking, gadgets, and Chung's amazing direction. Chung's games have always been about packing the world with detail and secrets and story and meaning, and QC sort of brings that out mechanically too - you need to understand the environment to find solutions, and that means you end up paying attention to all the small touches and flourishes in each world.

Timings and leaderboards sort of put an unnecessary pressure on gameplay, and it can make it tempting to rush in and power through to the best solution. I can't see a way to turn them off, but I recommend just sort of breezing through it on your first run and not worrying about optimality. It's best to take each little place as it comes, and poke and explore it to get the most out of it.

It's fun! I'm still playing through it. But it's a good time.
 
mike

Recommandé
12.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 7 avril 2020
Thanks to the Humble Bundle I was able to come across this little gem. Had no idea what I was really getting into, but upon starting the game, I was instantly hooked.

So the part of the company's shtick I guess is not describing too much of the game on the front page, so it makes it hard for people to decide whether or not to buy it. But if you're into problem solving that requires some patience, this is the game for you. The cyber punk voxel visuals really fit in well and adds to the game's charm. Yes, there is some aspects of coding, but it's more of a tease than anything substantial, I actually do wish there was a lot more commands you could tinker with. However this makes sense given the actual length of the game, which is it's only huge drawback.

I beat the game in 12 hours, and for the price I paid for the Humble Bundle it was definitely worth it. But for 20 dollars I'd say get it if you want to support more games like this to come out. This is definitely a small but charming game, the puzzles aren't too crazy but you do really get the feeling of being a hacker.

Évaluation publiée le 10 aout 2016
This is the kind of game where, if I'd paid <10$ for it, I'd be happy with it.
Points for originality, certainly. However, I find this game lacking in actual playability. It's oddly paced, unengaging, and the puzzles are so linear that they don't really feel like you're being clever when you solve them.
There are elements of gameplay that feel pointless, and a few times they warn you of consequences that don't actually occur.
I feel like this game was oversold. If it had been a small release and not costing $20, I think it would feel like less of a cheat.

Greyvy
0
3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
4.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 30 novembre 2022
An orchestra with no conductor

I believe videogames to be like musical compositions. Having an array of great elements, no matter how excellent, will not be sufficient unless they are ordered in a harmonic setup enabling appropriate kind of synergetic result to emerge. Pathologic 2 did not affect me as much as it did with just aesthetics, gameplay, or setpieces. It was so powerful because every single element was constantly interacting with every other piece of the puzzle. The biggest problem of Quadrilateral Cowboy is the internal disjointedness.

It has an intriguing story set in interesting setting. It's told mostly without words - used sparingly here, and with no dialogue at all. Short scenes between the heists are full of character, and succeed at creating an atmosphere of disempowerment, sending a message of solidarity in dire conditions and personal bonds subsisting through (and despite) overwhelming pauperisation. My personal favourite was the theme running in the background parallel to main plot, given explicit recognition only at few points in the game. Compassion fatigue, as we can quite literally read on main character's shirt, that is the continuous suppression of moral conscience of a person who has no autonomy over their actions anymore. On some of the levels you may catch yourself questioning the ethical permissibility of what you are about to do - but still do it anyway, because you have no other way to progress. You have no choice, just like your in-game character. MAKE AN HONEST MORAL INVENTORY OF YOURSELF, asks the receptionist bot before you steal brain of a patient in a coma ward

It has gameplay ideas that work. There's a lot of fun tools for you to play around with! You can remotely hack into devices in the local network, you may set up a turret sending precise projectiles into pre-programmed spots, there is a little puppy-like remote controlled bot able to crawl through narrow spaces.

But none of these tools interact with each other. Your deck, a portable computer you use to control your equipment with terminal commands, comes equipped with command chaining feature. There is nothing stopping you from chaining six turret commands, and in fact you have to do it at some point to solve time-based puzzles. There is, however, something stopping you from chaining puppy with turret or hacking commands. Every tool requires you to enter separate application for controls, meaning that you cannot invoke Puppy, move 10 steps forward while running the app for turret controls. The design of the levels, fully aware of this limitation, never expects you to use more than one tool at a time. It makes most of the game feel like an extensive introduction to the game proper - but there is no game proper. Last two levels feel like an unsuccessful attempt to create something that would require the player to employ their creativity in not just how do I use this tool? way, but also which tool do I use?. It's still nothing but compartmentalised single-tool puzzles connected with corridors.

All in all, Quadrilateral Cowboy feels like a textbook definition of unrealised potential. All the pieces are there - but the game lacks vision. There is no space for player creativity, and the game seems hesitant to challenge the player. It missed the mark for proper balance between challenge and accessibility, leaning too much in favour of the latter.

However, I still do recommend giving this game a try. Despite the gameplay failings, it is not at any point unenjoyable. There is still a place for these typical puzzle game I'm so smart! moments, and the story, themes and setting are genuinely captivating. With how short it is, it doesn't really make you bored at any time - the disappointment hits only after the game is over, with Wait, so that's it? and the following moment of reflection.

And if finished playthrough leaves you with taste for more gameplay in this vein, I wholeheartedly recommend checking out Ctrl Alt Ego. In my opinion, it successfully materialised the idea of Quadrilateral Cowboy - that is an idea of free form puzzle/immersive sim game it never fully became.
 
Margaritea
641 produits enregistrés

I wanted to finish this game, and if it ever gets fixed, I will.

Until then, I can't recommend anyone to get the game.

It's mostly a "heist simulation" game, but it subtly interweaves the various characters' personalities into the game.

You won't need to read into it to enjoy it, but you will if you want to understand why the characters are the way they are.

Recommandé
7.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 26 mars 2021
A beautifully tight yet complex game about using command lines to manipulate devices to steal things from people and with a lovely art style reflective of times when processing speeds where measured in terms of kilobytes.

They could have this game overwhelming in terms of level design but I think they nailed it with tight levels with a more or less singular focus on a given function at least until the last 2-3 levels where everything really comes together. There's some really clever ways to break levels but even that requires thinking so far outside of the box that you'll have to pick up your brain afterwards.

The ending was unexpectedly heavy but in a really sweet way and the fact Blendo was able to tell a story that is as much about friendships and the passing of time as it is about manually adjusting the angle of your aimbot-enabled sniper rifle in order to shoot the laser grid deactivation button via embedded command prompts ('blinks') so you can safely advance your remotely connected scout bot ('weever') is a genuine achievement.
 
Xavier: Renegade Angel

Non recommandé
8.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 2 aout 2016
There's just nothing here to recommend. I was excited for this release thanks to my enjoyment of Thirty Flights of Loving, but this game just feels... empty. The gameplay never goes anywhere beyond basic introductions of the mechanics. Every other level intoduces a new method of solving the puzzles then quickly abandons them in favor of another.

The biggest let down, for me, was the plot. Or the lack of one. Refering to Thirty Flights of Loving again, that game managed to tell a stronger story in ten minutes than this game did in 4 hours. The characters don't do anything. There's no conflict to resolve, no obstacle to overcome. Everything goes perfectly well for these characters.

It's such a shame, too, because as you look through the developer's commentary you see Brendon Chung's enthusiasm for his project. He spent much of his attention in the finer details of this world he created.
 
LemurLord12

4 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
6.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 9 avril 2020
First of all I will start by saying that this is probably one of the more unique and curiosity-driven games I've played in a while: Everything from the weird syntax, the small text in all the places, the objects, the background details that fill the lore... It's really pulls that explorative part of your brain and I think the people behind this game were aiming for that.

However there is one glaring flaw and it's that it feels more like a tech demo than a game: It's fairly short (it doesn't matter that a couple of missions make you stop and think), there are many different play styles thrown in, there are some heavy bugs (I managed to get stuck in many walls and the computer's command shortcuts glitch out at every corner, making it a chore to type when you can't even use the autocomplete nor the command history), the style aims more for the quirks than for the lore (which is subjective to be honest)... All on top that the game is (at the time of this review) priced at $20, a number it doesn't earn by any chance.

If the people were aiming to try different techniques, styles, routes and ways to do games I congratulate them because there are some good ideas here, but selling it as a full game is actually harmful to them; I can't in good conscience recommend this one and I'm not going to buy any of their other games in the near future
 
BSummers

5.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 28 décembre 2022
Never have I played a game with such an unexpectedly brilliant ending, and combining that with enjoyable gameplay and a unique style has left us with a wonderful short game!

If you enjoyed the quirk of Gravity Bone or Thirty Flights of loving, but didn't like their short playtime (totalling up to around 25 minutes) or lack of much challenging gameplay, then you will most likely enjoy Quadrilateral Cowboy; as long as you're ready to face a plethora of programming-based heists, set in a corporate-controlled-retro-cyberpunk world.

Sidenote, the addition of optional developer commentaries in Blendo Games' projects is really nice and provides a really interesting insight into the mind of the developer!
 
Alferu
283 produits enregistrés
0
6 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
6.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 19 février 2018
My first encounter with this game was while it was in development. It was being shown in a trailer at a PAX show, and it seemed like it was going to be the first game to allow the player to use programming to solve interactive problems in a FPS. I was pretty excited for that, but after years in development and waiting for the macOS port, I see that it changed a lot from its early vision. What remains is an incredible aesthetic but an easy and short 5 hour game where your band of 3 lady hackers complete a series of virtual heists. There are puzzles, but they are light scripting if you can even call it that. Nothing that feels like programming ever comes into it. You'll "jack in" to wall sockets and trigger this and that with keyboard commands, but mostly it follows the tradition of "find the door trigger that opens the door". With the twist being that sometimes you have to place a remotely triggered device and work on your timing. There is no multiplayer, despite the introduction of a gameplay style halfway through the game where you have to switch between two characters to cooperatively solve tasks in tandem.

The gameplay changes every stage or two, and it doesn't build upon itself necessarily. It's just continually experimenting with ideas and then throwing them away. You're on a train, you're robbing a house, you're in space now. Robots attack your hideout. You're on an airship. A badminton mini-game. All right...I get it, this game wants you to know it's quirky.

Anyway, beyond some light brainteasers, this is a game about the visual art. Quadrilateral Cowboy has no dialogue or plot, moving between discrete and disconnected missions with only wah-wah-wah Charlie Brown style dialogue, if any at all. It's strictly visual storytelling. It fitting with the hipster aesthic, the game is set in a fictional 1979 or 1980, with plenty of retro computing artifacts and obvious influences from Wes Andersen's cinematic style.

The soundtrack consists of a handful of public domain tunes from the early 20th century (plus a recurring rendition of Claire de Lune) which the player can select from at any time, using a walkman-like portable record-player item. Visually, the game is a cross between dark cyberpunk and an absurdist comedy, similar to JazzPunk. Thanks to the idTech4 engine, it runs at a good frame rate on an old mid-2010 MacBook Pro.

I would recommend the game if you are a fan of charming indie efforts, but do not look for a serious programmer-style challenge along the lines of a Zachtronics game. The controls are clumsy, especially when trying to place your deck or TV on the ground. Multiple bugs will affect your gameplay – mostly minor, but in my short playthrough it crashed to the main menu or crashed out of the game entirely more than once. Another bug can cause your character to "choke from lack of oxygen" in any outer-space level where you are safely indoors.
 
mike.myers

While not the best executed, this games concept is truly intriguing. It is moddable, so I can't wait to see what the community does with it. The game feels almost tame, like theres a lot more that can be done but it shies away from it. Again I feel like the moddability is going to be responsible for most of this games longevity. I really do like it though, the feel it gives you can be sometimes described as magical, giving me a rush as if I really were hacking my way into a heavily guarded establishment.

Quadrilateral Cowboy gets an 8/10

Non recommandé
4.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 16 décembre 2017
It's a decent concept but never gets off the ground. Unlike the terminal hacker sims it's frequently compared to, your goal in each level is just to use the mechanic exactly as it's presented to you, and most of the losses you experience will occur because of the wonky physics engine or the game not clearly explaining which devices you can only disable for set intervals; rather than needing to actually rethink and refine your code. There's a particularly exhausting level in which you have to wait MINUTES at a time for a quadrupedal drone to shamble across a plain room to the mission objective, after which your completing or repeating the entire mission depends on a physics object whose trajectory you can't telegraph landing in the right place.
Halfway through, the gameplay changes completely and no longer includes the hacking element at all; becoming a thoroughly generic and uninteresting timing-based strategy platformer like a clunkier Braid.

Would not recommend, especially not to someone who loved Uplink and Hacknet and is looking for the next big thing - this isn't it.
 
Ekvivu
0
3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
6.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 28 juillet 2016
I think this game has some great possibilities, but it seems a lot is still lacking. Game is buggier then a bethesda on a good day, but a lot of that can be overlooked (one man dev studio, is probably going to have many bugs), as of now there are tons of bugs.

This is a puzzle game, very similiar to portal or talos principle, so if you enjoy those games, you will enjoy this. If you're a fan of Blendo games, you will get more of what you loved in the previous games he's released. If not, but you enjoy puzzle games, I would wait for a more polished released.

Mods are probably what will make the game really fun, as it supports them and I can't wait for more people to get into it.
 
Duraldo

16.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 1 aout 2016
Imagine if Wes Anderson and Quentin Tarantino made a cyberpunk heist game.

Even though Quadrilateral Cowboy game draws on the aesthetics and mood of Chung’s previous games Gravity Bone and Thirty Flights of Loving, it has a much richer gameplay experience and a lighter (and longer) story. The puzzles are insane and fun to solve, all wrapped in a simple-polygon future version of the eighties - with wacky devices and impossible scenarios.

For me? A must-buy.
 
eric

Évaluation publiée le 17 décembre 2023
I feel compelled to write a review about Quad Cowboy, though I haven’t played it in years, because I think about it constantly. As an artist and developer it’s a constant source of inspiration. The toolkit and respect it dolls to the player is really unique. The holistic aesthetic vision is glued to the mechanics in a way that’s really sticky in your memory: nothing is like Quad Cowboy.

Sure I have criticisms but the best art isn’t perfect. Would take a QC2 any day!

However for an indie effort, this game is really quite excellent and I highly recommend it.

1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
4.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 30 juillet 2016
First Impressions Video:

Vidéo YouTube™: Takin' a Look at... Quadrilateral Cowboys 
Vues : 60
Today we check out Quadrilateral Cowboys. This is a strange little puzzle game about hacking. We may have no clue why we're hacking, but at least we get the jobs done.


Quadrilateral Cowboys is a crazy ride. It's not without its flaws, but it's a great time.

Basically, QC (because that name is WAY too long) is about being freelance "hackers" who steal stuff. Most of the game is an interplay between the real world around you and console commands that you type into your deck (in game computer).

The game is set in a strange cyber punk 80's setting. A probably dystopian society and more weirdness around every corner makes the world enjoyable to be in.

Now, the gameplay. This sits in a weird space for me. I really like it. The concepts behind it are great and the execution is enjoyable, but the levels never allow the depth that one would expect from a puzzle game. Every level brings in a new ability and each of those levels is focused on that thing. In other words, every level asks you "do you know how to use this ability?" but no level ever delves into the interplay between the abilities. I was always expecting to find a big level with complex puzzles necessitating the use of all of the skills I'd learned so far, but that level never came. Plus, the puzzles aren't that difficult. Most of the time I could easily see what needed to done, and succeeding was just a matter of things out.

But it's not al bad, because I've enjoyed the experience. The game was definitely fun, just not as fun as it could have been.

In the end, QC is unique and definitely worth the time, but it never manages to mature into a serious puzzle game. Is it worth picking up? At $20, I would say that if you really want to check it out, you can pick it up. If you're only interested in it, wait until it's on sale for around $10, because it's definitely worth that price.
 
Vinrafel

2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
3.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 23 décembre 2020
It's a short and sweet game, and I enjoyed myself, but I have to admit, it was a little lacking in challenge for me in the end. Felt like the game was building up to a big complex heist, and then suddenly it was already over without me ever having to flex all of the stuff I'd learned.

It's greatest strength is also its greatest weakness: every new mission introduces some new tech for you to use and builds up the complexity bit-by-bit. This has the effect of having a great amount of variation and novelty to the gameplay, but it also has the effect of making it feel like you're constantly going through tutorials. Missions are also very bite-size and standalone, not really mixing together all of the tech you've learned into anything connected, leading, as I said before, to feeling a bit like "that was it?" once you get to the end.

I still had a good time with the game, especially due to the charming atmosphere of the game where there is practically no HUD, with all information introduced diegetically/in-world through things like manuals and buttons and labels. I guess I'd just say its a cautionary tale where people expecting some sort of huge hacking/coder/heister challenge like a cyberpunk Hitman or a Zachtronics game might be a bit disappointed in how easy this game can be. However, for people who aren't coders at all, or perhaps like a more easy, story-based game, I think you'll get your moneys worth.
 
FutureCop
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
5.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 8 décembre 2022
Wow, just... Wow. This is easily without a doubt one of my favorite puzzle games of all time. And that's standing probably besides portal 2 and superliminal. I really, really, really love this game and I have quite a bit to say about it. But if you want the tldr, you play as a heister hacker. And for 90% of the game, you use your hacking deck would you manually type into to use for your unique gadgets and to hack things like doors, cameras, etc. If that sounds cool to you, this game is 100% worth it.

Though if you're you want a longer review, then keep reading because like I said, I have quite a bit to say about this. This is one of the most unique puzzle games I've played in such a long time for multiple reasons. But the star of the show is your hacking deck, instead of something like Watch Dogs we're hacking is reduced to a single button press. Quadrilateral Cowboy requires you to type out your commands and they lean hard into this. And although that sounds complicated, quadrilateral Cowboy teaches this mechanic is such an intuitive and simple way. At first you might be confused with the gadget but after messing around with it for a little bit, you Master it.

Instead of having little tutorial pop-ups which tells you the controls, quadrilateral Cowboy teaches you its mechanics through its environments, on the hacking deck itself and even in a little notebook you carry around. At first you will be daunted with the new gadgets, but with a little time of experimenting with them, they're almost second nature. And even if you're daunted about how to use them later on in the game, you'll soon figure out how you're supposed to use it in a set level.

Something interesting among the many interesting things about this game is the setup. In quadrilateral cowboy, there is multiple steps to completing a level. You're exploring the environment, you're planning, you're testing then you actually put it through into fruition. As simple as I make that sound, it can be a slow and maybe even long process. But in a way it's like a game of dominoes. For the harder puzzles, this becomes so satisfying, seeing this almost Rube Goldberg of Domino's that you set up fall perfectly into place. This game is only 5 hours long but the setup for each level makes it feel so much longer. After finally finishing the game, I didn't feel like it was too short of an experience. I felt just satisfied, feeling like I spent 10 hours instead of five. This game felt like the longest 5 hours of my life, the quadrilateral Cowboy can spin that into a good thing because of how fun it is.

Though unfortunately, I still do have my problems with this game. This might be completely subjective but I felt like most of the levels were a bit easy. Not to mention most of the environments are small so that Rube Goldberg I was mentioning feels way shorter. Granted there was a couple of levels that got me stumped for a moment but there wasn't a point in the game where I felt the level was complicated which for something like this, I would have heavily adored.

And my other problem and this one kind of breaks my heart, this isn't really something the devs can even control. This game has a Steam Workshop but over the 6 years since it's release, it's only accumulated eight mods Total. Six of them are maps, two of them is joke mods. This breaks my heart because this game has so, so, so much to work with. The community can really make something that I'm yearning for which is more complicated puzzles.

This is something that kind of confused me and I'll have to stay vague for this but once you come to that moment, you'll see what I mean. I believe it is two-three levels before the two final levels of the game. They introduce a completely different mechanic that practically dropped the hacking deck entirely until the last two levels. An admittedly, I preferred the hacking deck over this new mechanic but it was still something interesting. But it was strangely short-lived, I don't even know how to explain it in a vague way. But you'll see exactly what I mean when you'll come to it, not at all bad, it's actually an interesting mechanic. But I just wish it was used in Tangent with the hacking deck.

Quadrilateral Cowboy is such a special game to me, every time I log off the game, my mind just starts racing for what gadget, puzzle or whatever will meet me next. When I play this game, I'm talking to myself, experimenting with the gadgets and trying to aim or direct them in the best position I can. Even after I beat the game, I get this excited feeling in my heart after playing this. It was super satisfying doing this entire planning process, lining all of the Domino's in the right spots and unfortunately, I don't think there will really be an experienced like this again.

If I had to rate this game, it would be a rock solid 8 out of 10, this is easily one of my favorite puzzle games of all time. And this would have been the game that would have beaten Portal 2 and superliminal for me if it wasn't for the lack of in the workshop support and the lack of more complicated levels. Although I know hacking games completely aren't a new thing and quadrilateral Cowboy just innovated it. But I felt like quadrilateral Cowboy is still way more unique than those other games. Please buy this game, I know I'm 6 years late to this but this is such an amazing game

And to blendo games, I doubt you're reading this but regardless of how long it takes, if it takes 10, 20 years or whatever. I would absolutely love to see a sequel for this game or at least a spiritual successor. Thank you for giving me and many other players such a amazing experience with this game and I'm looking forward to your other projects, especially Skin Deep.
 
Lieutenant Beard

41.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 26 septembre 2023
Produit reçu gratuitement

Full disclosure: I made the release trailer for this!

If you want to be Dennis Nedry from that scene in Jurassic Park where he's programmed the computers to perfectly disable the security systems on his way to the dinosaur embryos, this is the game for you. I will never be a programmer, but this game has just the right balance of typing things into a console and making things happen in the world. It makes you FEEL like a hacker, at least, a movie version of a hacker who does a bunch of typing then says: "I'm in!"

It's a heist game where you don't need to stress. More like a jewel thief type scenario where the enemies are the security systems set in place. Fun fact: The game's systems made it super easy to capture footage for this trailer because I could synchronize and time things to happen according to my chosen choreography and timing.

This is a super unique game. The graphics are lo-fi, but endearing and detailed in their own way. Absolutely recommended!

КРУТОЙ ПОЦ
201 produits enregistrés
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
8.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 4 novembre 2021
Quadrilateral Cowboy é um jogo em que você é realiza roubos hackeando dispositivos. Diferente de outros jogos onde a opção de hack está atrelada a um minigame bobo (Deus Ex, BioShock, Prey etc.), neste aqui o hackeamento é realizado via linha de comando, sendo ao mesmo tempo complicado e divertido (quem tem familiaridade com lógica de programação vai gostar bastante).
Depois de algumas missões, você consegue vincular linhas de comando às piscadas de seu personagem (com o botão Q). É nesse momento que Quadrilateral Cowboy entrega o que tem de melhor, permitindo planejar e executar os roubos de maneira rápida e inteligente.
Infelizmente a curta campanha principal não aproveita totalmente disso. Muitas das missões existem somente para ensiná-lo a usar dispositivos individuais; mas a união final de todos esses elementos é muito breve. Eu senti que assim que aprendi sobre todos os sistemas do jogo, tive poucas oportunidades de aplicar o conjunto completo de dispositivos e conhecimentos além da missão final.
É preciso dizer que, além da campanha desnivelada nas dificuldades das missões, existem alguns problemas com o jogo: ele travou várias vezes e é comum ocorrer pequenos bugs (solicitar corretamente que uma porta abra e ela não abrir, por exemplo). Esses problemas não prejudicarem seriamente meu tempo com o jogo. É um jogo de quebra-cabeça bem divertido, inteligente e cheio de personalidade.
Infelizmente a comunidade é pequena e há na oficina da Steam uns 6 pacotes de missões criados por usuários, caso queira jogar mais do que a missão principal.
 
pipa

Recommandé
17.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 2 novembre 2019
One of the most satisfying gaming experiences I've ever had. Blendo understands how to apply cinema editing techniques to games without interfering with interactivity, their use of short scenes and cuts punches the story home and provides emotional beats. It also creates a realized world without requiring a 100-person dev team. Though the world is small physically it is full of details for those who like to look around and pick everything up too.

This is a cyberpunk hacking game that understands that if physical violence is required then things have gone to hell. This game is about terminals and scripts, it is about planning and executing that plan. It is a stealth game that is not about waiting for guards to walk around. It's about being ride-or-die for the people you love.

Recommend if you enjoy: Zachtronics games (SpaceChem, Magnum Opus), Portal 1/2, Hitman, PUBG, Metal Gear Solid series, Wolfenstein reboots, movies in general
 
Senor.Roboto
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
3.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 6 janvier 2018
Quadrilateral Cowboy is an enjoyable game with a quirky art style. It constantly introduces new and interesting mechanics before you can get bored with any of them. The short campaign (which was approximately 3.5 hours) serves as a great showcase for all the abilities, but I think Quadrilateral Cowboy’s true potential would be community made maps/heists. The game gives the player amazing tools, but doesn’t fully utilize them; Something that would be perfect for community made maps. Unfortunately there is no level editor like in Portal 2 to allow for the small community to produce content without knowing how to fully mod, in external programs.

Overall, without a level editor to reach its true potential, Quadrilateral Cowboy offers amazing tools but does not fully utilize them. I would recommend picking this one up on sale.
 
Obvious Spy

流程非常地短，6个小时就通关了。一个非常神奇的黑客游戏。一开始是用笔记本来黑各种门和激光器来偷东西。每一个关卡结束都会给你一件新的黑客道具，每件都很有创意。整个流程里人物之间没有对白，但是好像还是能明白发生了点什么，到最后三个人在一起干杯有种迷之浪漫的感觉，虽然只过了6个小时但感觉就是过了很久。68很难说值不值，但这么一个小众游戏估计就是不会打折的把。可能是目前黑客游戏里最好的了。
