6.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 28 juillet 2016
This is overall a very beautiful game and a very unique experience. It's exactly what you would expect from playing Blendo's previous standalone 3D games Gravity Bone and Thirty Flights of Loving. It's longer and grander than both of those, but it shares many of their traits, such as Blendo's unique storytelling methods and his great worldbuilding, using techniques like magic realism and implied plot. The gameplay is more focused in this game than in his others (they didn't have much in terms of puzzles or things like that) and it adds to the game significantly. The hacking mechanics are very well done and it's very fun to use all the gadgets.

The only flaws with this game are that the missions are linear puzzles without much replayability (actually not any replayability at all unless you feel like getting more immersed in the gorgeous world or want to go for a better time on the arbitrary leaderboards) and the many crashes experienced during play. Blendo is, however, working progressively and diligently to eliminate bugs and crashes so by time anyone reads this, the crashes will probably be fixed.

Overall I feel it was worth the $20, but if you want a longer game (it's about 4 hours long), or expect sandboxey levels ala deus ex and an in-your-face story, then you probably won't enjoy it. This game can be summed up as 30 flights of loving multiplied by 10 with keyboard hacking ala command prompt and a couple neat gadgets (remote controlled robot, autoturret, springboard-type launcher) so if that doesn't sound appealing, don't buy it.
 
Gup Gup
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
5.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 26 janvier 2022
My Experience

Although this game is from 2016, it's easily one of the top 20 games I played last year (2021). For the longest time, I was convinced that it would be too tedious. I've never been the biggest fan of puzzle games, and entering commands in the console seemed so complicated. I finally decided to come back to it after scouring the Steam store for games classified as "immersive sims" and seeing Blendo's creation so prominently featured.

There's something about this style of gameplay that is just immensely satisfying, making games feel so interactive and immersive. The control that the player has over so many different systems provides a sense of agency that is almost unparalleled. It doesn't hurt that this particular game has such an excellent wrapping as well. I found the visual design of the characters and tools consistently amusing, and I loved the merger between the cyberpunk genre and the relative lack of sophistication that was present in 90's tech. It made the game feel authentic without feeling overly complex.

There are a couple of times when the game seems to demand precise timing or particularly accurate movement (or at least, the solutions that I devised did). It can be a little frustrating to feel like you know the solution to a puzzle but are unable to execute it correctly. However, these moments aren't super common.

If solving puzzles with a collection of vintage-feeling tech sounds like it would be fun to you, I can wholeheartedly recommend Quadrilateral Cowboy. I've never seen anything else quite like it.
 
frontman12
660 produits enregistrés
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
6.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 11 décembre 2018
The intricacies of getting old

Although intimidating on trailers, the game is very easy and accesible if you are open minded in the various ways of doing the puzzles. Some are very innovative and make you feel inside the character you're playing; a lack of consistency among this should be mentioned, because even though the vast majority of them seem interesting on paper, once you have narrowed down the formula in the first 3, the game feels extremely easy.

The gameplay aspect of the game feels a bit lacking as a consequence because it doesn't try to evolve into something more complex or deeper. It touches lots of new mechaniqs and it falls sort when it tries to make you use them in a level, the fact that you can 'cheat' the way the puzzles are made to be done, like for example letting a turret shot a box in order to fall of a cliff makes the game very easy. Evey level you feel the potential of the game to be something deeper but like a bubble, it explodes when you get closer.

The plot is very short and and simple but speaks about growing in a very mature manner, you may be a hacker, but you are a worker and must wake up at 6 am. One day you have to start from scratch, and one day an old picture reminds you that time gone will never go back.
 
Spartan_Rambo
303 produits enregistrés
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
40.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 27 septembre 2016
Man oh man I love this game.

It is definitely not for everyone, but for some of you this will be the most satisfying game you will play. The artwork is fantastic; zaney, techy and surreal, very reminiscent of Jazzpunk , a style that I'm pretty crazy for.

On top of that, there's some mild in-game programming. It's a simplified command line (MS-DOS) and doesn't require any coding experience, but if you do have some previous exposure you may have fun writing some recursive batch files, at your own risk that is :)

Only draw back to this fantastic game is that it's a bit short (i.e. it's exactly like Jazzpunk). My play through was a little shy of 8 hours, though I think for others it may be a little shorter as I like to really take in the scenery and perfect my solutions to games like this.

TL;DR - This game is a work of art, and like all art some people will appreciate it more than others. For some it will be the best game ever, while others may hate it. My advice? Give it a shot!
 
Lmod

Recommandé
11.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 14 septembre 2019
I just love hacking in games and Quadrilateral Cowboy is one of the best examples of it. With a nice visual style to boot you'll be breaking into and out of a myriad of places while completing contracts for... well, who knows who. It starts out simple with just quick jacking in and activating pre-placed commands but before long you'll be timing gun shots to your movement and activating your robot buddy with a blink of your eye. Literally.

The game takes a light touch to presenting a story but there definitely is one there if you're willing to look. I like the way the developer makes the story opt in which feels like it rewards you for keeping your mind and eye open to any info. And I found the developer commentary to be a nice addition though I just wish there was more of it in the game!

All in all, highly recommended!

Évaluation publiée le 27 juillet 2016
Another brilliant game from Blendo Games. The art style is simple but attractive, and the core gameplay is great. I found it a bit Portal-esque, in that some of the puzzles stopped me up for a little while, but it was never terribly frustrating and I always felt clever when I solved it.

I also really liked the cyberpunk-in-the-80s style of all the interfaces, and the little story interludes between missions were great. Very atmospheric and evocative when they needed to be.

Recommandé
10.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 8 aout 2016
I completely love you, Blendo Games!
You elevate gaming into high art. Please keep doing the work you have been doing, and especially if you continue to add to Quadrilateral Cowboy, an already excellent and complete game.

Review: This game is full of cyberpunk "jobs" that you do with two other characters, in a fully stylized world. With the use of multiple gadgets and hacking, you can use an easy to learn programming language to utilize them to break into highly secured places. Its a bit of a challenge to program multiple tasks, but it is very open ended in how you can do your programming. About 2 missions were a bit of a pain, due to me trying to figure out how not to get stuck in laser grids, but they were doable, and most of the many missions are not so very hard to figure out.
I recommend this game to anyone who wants to challenge themselves with a game that uses objects and coding together to complete objectives, and anyone that has enjoyed Blendo Games work before.
THE LARGEST PRO: The game itself is strangely emotional, and beautiful. The gameplay is solid but the unfolding of the group, without dialogue, and how they live and work together is just first rate. Not many games replicate the narrative as well, with so much minimalism, as this game amazingly does. By the time it was over, I was suprised to be as emotionally invested as I was.

Come for the fun H@x0rz, stay for the deep emotional bond that develops.
 
repdetect0

3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
5.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 31 mai 2023
It has a lot of potentially fun ideas but doesn't really go anywhere. Very short. Feels like a tech demo, it's basically a series of tutorials on your gadgets.

It's also absolutely bug ridden, I had at least ten crashes apparently caused by right clicking to pick up objects. The Linux and (apparently) Mac versions have a game-breaking bug that makes the clinic level unfinishable without using debug console commands as 3/4 buttons on the level don't actually do anything when activated. The state of the game sometimes doesn't reset properly when you restart the level, objects remain where they were, alarms instantly sound, etc until you completely exit and open the level again. Sometimes pressing up while on your deck immediately inputs the last command instead of just displaying it, I couldn't find any consistent logic to what causes it.
 
Hekatonkheires
1,648 produits enregistrés
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
6.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 2 novembre 2020
Quadrilateral Cowboy is fantastic. I added it to my wish list years ago because I loved Gravity Bone and Thirty Flights Of Loving, but it took a long time for me to get around to buying it. It's not quite as good as those two games, but it is much longer, which is nice. You play a criminal who plans out heists for your criminal buddies. Over the course of the game you unlock more and more zany gadgets to crack ever-more-elaborate security measures. The heists are absurd and hilarious, and the scenes between them are the highlight of the game. Unfortunately toward the end of the game the heists start becoming more timing-based, so you're likely to screw them up and then have to replay several times over (you can't save mid-heist), which ruins the pacing of the story. Still, it is a really cool story and the minor frustration toward the end is worth it for the overall experience.

Recommandé
4.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 15 novembre 2016
I loved Gravity Bone and Thirty Flights of Loving, and no surprise, I love QC too. The understated narrative (lack of dialogue, reliance on environment, visual design) is brilliant and unique to these games I feel - it is so much more effective than any other way to tell a story I've seen in video games, and leaves a lot up to me as a player which is awesome and bold and needed in more games! The puzzling is great and satisfying, and the visual and audio design tie it all together wonderfully.

Mega plus for GNU/Linux version as well, and for how well it works even on my quite crappy hardware, with lots of graphic settings to tweak!

If you like a warm but subtly terrifying story, immersive game play all delivered with great unique style, go for it! Well worth the full price for anyone, and I am sure it will have a long happy life of mods and updates! I will upgrade to deluxe edition as soon as I get a paycheck!
 
buena
247 produits enregistrés
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
12.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 4 janvier 2022
Heists! Do you like them? Alternate worlds that are almost like a steampunks take on cyberpunk. The world is megacorperations, dark alley dealers, and your friends. Check out the last screenshot on the store page for fantasy cyberpunk mix.

Super imaginative world, that you can explore as a hacking trio. What better way to use your engineering degrees than to create a startup specialising on planning perfect heists (without the risks of the heists themselves).

The gameplay: mission based, with some story / tutorials in between. The missions send you into these highly unique structures, each with their own challenges in how to navigate them. Is it in space? so then there will be the vacuum of space outside, are there lasers, timers, switches, ect? Your tool, the deck, you carry with you setting it down on a surface when needed to search for nearby connections to hack into, or manipulate in some way.

The world: If you are on the fence check out gravity bone (free) by the same developer, or thirty flights of loving.

Don't think the game is for everyone, but the world and game-play are pretty special.
 
jersi

11.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 6 décembre 2021
Peak Blendo.

Absolutely perfect Blendo-punk aesthetic, and a truly excellent hacking platform and great levels designed around such mechanics.

It does certainly take some learning, iterating, and practice, but each level seems to help underscore the importance of each tool and sort of pokes you to think of how to implement and chain the tools together.

I can't code for anything, but this I feel really helps me use that type of procedural logic much better.

1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile

Recommandé
4.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 6 juillet 2019
I picked up an ashtray - just a random ashtray that was lying around - and then dropped it on the floor accidentally. I thought to myself - with the level of detail in this game, I wouldn't be surprised if the devs had modelled the ash falling out...

I picked the ashtray up again. They had.

I think that says something about the charm and love and effort put into Quadrilateral Cowboy. It's one of those short-but-sweet games - a concentrated burst of fun that leaves more of an impression in 10 minutes than most games do in 10 hours. There is a stunning level of detail put into every scene, from the aforementioned interactivity to the well-written signs and product boxes.

The gameplay is a ton of fun too, combining Hitman-esque planning with some good old-fashioned command-line hacking. When you crack the solution and watch all the parts come together, it's a great feeling.

As others have noted, it's short, but every minute of its 4-5 hours made me smile. There are so many ideas packed into this game, it's a shame they aren't expanded on more. In particular the two levels where you have to plan out the actions of two characters to run simultaneously (open the door for your buddy - wait 30 seconds for them to go in and unlock a door - go through that door etc.) is such a fantastic idea that could easily fill out a whole game.

I really enjoyed Gravity Bone and Thirty Flights of Loving - again, very short games that I can remember more vividly than games I played for 30+ hours. I skipped this when it came out because I heard it got some average reviews, but that was a mistake. If Blendo's style is your bag, you'll like it!
 
Sum0
493 produits enregistrés

6 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile

Non recommandé
6.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 11 septembre 2016
Can't recommend this due to a lot of bugs. It started out as fun, but later bugs make the levels unfinishable. Later levels require a lot of time and patience, and nothing is more frustrating then almost getting to the end, only to have your character suddenly die of O2 deprivation while you're INSIDE the space station. Another bug prevents you from seeing the output from the deck, which also required me to start over. Another bug has your little robot (Weever) suddenly just disappear.

The game is a lot of fun, and as a developer I love the command-line mechanics, too bad it's just plagued by a bunch of game breaking bugs.

Évaluation publiée le 27 décembre 2017
Honesty i love the game. Although it goes around between 2 or 3 different gameplay mechanics that change the whole game instead of doing a deus ex pull of giving you several ways to complete an objective with a single one, its still fascinating. The ending really isn't much more difficult than the rest of the game if at all anyways, and sometimes it feels like if the levels are too short and simple like to take advantage of all the tools that you unlock by the late game. But in aesthetic, storytelling, and audio design i really love the game.

I paid about what. 10 bucks? i dont know if its worth the 20 that i think the full price is but if its 15 or below you are really gonna get a very nice experience. Specially with such a pretty ending.

5.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 12 décembre 2019
The game is good and unique. it's got a fairly decent story about a bunch of friends and who take jobs and do some pretty cool ♥♥♥♥. it's a nice story and has plenty of unique game mechanics. however it's failing is the fact that it doesn't really expand or play with any of the ideas it presents. or brings up. a good example of this is when you have to time your actions with copies of your past self. you THINK it's gonna be really cool. until all of a sudden you get all the upgrades yourself. and that's that. now that mechanics out the window.

really the entire game is a massive tutorial. the real stuff is on the community workshop. i haven't ventured there myself but seeing as how there's a "Mods" folder on the main menu, it seems this was the developers intention too.

so yes, it's a very fun game. interesting puzzle solving game. and here's a pro tip: the longer you spend in front of the deck to string commands together, the easier your life will be.

15.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 13 novembre 2023
grand theft rube goldberg cyberpunk hackerman matrix parallel timeline mission impossible heist simulator simulator.


most of my messing around with this game was on another Platform, but getting another copy to post a Review was something i was sure to do.

i think my leading remark mostly covers what there is to say about describing what the game is like. you're going to do some silly Heists that have you setting up some amusing fantasy chains of Equipment to steal some stuff or sabotage some stuff, or elsewise.
also compete with your Steam Friends for the best times on each Mission.
also there isn't quite just one right way to do each Mission. some things you still have to do like actually get to the target Room to steal the thing or break the thing, but how you get in and out, whether you're a ghost and nobody ever knew you were there, or you smash your way out with Guns blazing around you - up to you!
clean and quiet does score better, but hey, as long as you do the thing, the game doesn't care. success is success.


also this game runs on anything.

This game is extremely fun; however, for the amount of money for the game and amount of levels, it is not worth buying. If you happen to have 20$ in your steam wallet and love cliff hangers l, this is the game for you.

Non recommandé
9.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 29 mars 2020
Pros:
- Fun environmental puzzles using bits of an innovative pseudo-coding mechanic.
- Cute minimalist world-building and narrative.

♥♥♥♥:
- Some aspects of gameplay can be clunky control-wise, making maneuvering certain components into place under a time limit difficult. Most missions require looking at a screen within a screen which makes it hard to see important details.
- Tons of bugs and jank. Had to restart the game several times because it would get stuck in strange unplayable states. Somehow despite the blocky minimalist aesthetic this game made my 1080 Ti drop frames worse than DOOM or any modern AAA game.
- There's really only about 5-6 hours of gameplay here. For $20 such a short and unpolished product seems like a very poor value.

Quadrilateral Cowboy is quite a good programming game, it's simple style makes it easy to see the relevant information.

I didn't care about the story really, but it does add new gadgets to make each level interesting. I also didn't like how you couldn't achieve all objectives in a level at once, especially as the game is focus one type of play for its run.

It never reaches the variety that even the short "demo" Gravity Bone had where it was two quite different scenarios. In this game it's just basically the same thing - sneak into a place.

Évaluation publiée le 28 novembre 2016
Absolutely great puzzle game for combining elements of (very light) actual terminal input, planning, and exploration. The music, art, and story all work together well, and help it accomplish its overall goal. Really the only problem is a lack of content, but hopefully more will come out of the creators or mods. I made it through the game in about three hours, and probably could've gone faster if I was a bit more clever. The lack of levels makes it seem like you don't get to use all of the tools you're given to their full potential, but that potential is vast if this game gets a following.

2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
9.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 16 janvier 2017
Quadrilateral Cowboy ofrece una mecánica de hackeo, uso de herramientas y resolución de puzles muy satisfactoria, pero por desgracia falla en todos los demás aspectos.

-Gráficamente presenta multitud de texturas planas sobre fondos vectoriales, para representar entornos, que además son extremadamente surrealistas.
-La trama es muy abstracta, sin una narración clara, simple y muy poco elaborada.
-Las misiones parecen más prototipos de misiones sueltas, sin una continuidad argumental.
-Se echan de menos múltiples soluciones validas a cada puzle, sin que una sea necesariamente más fácil de abordar que otra.
-Si bien los MODS(escasos después de 6 meses desde su lanzamiento) son una baza a favor, pero que no hacen más que alargar un puñado de "frustrantes horas por lo que podría haber sido y no es Quadrilateral Cowboy".

Sinceramente pienso que ♥♥♥ un poco más de trabajo en mejorar el aspecto visual y el modo de narrar la historia, sería un juego digno de ser comparado ♥♥♥ PORTAL.
 
Baek

Non recommandé
4.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 2 décembre 2022
The game sets up an array of exciting tools and techniques, and you wait with bated breath for the game to finally begin and explore all their intriguing uses. You wait, only for the game to end, leaving with the deadening realisation that the missions you had been playing were not, in fact, an extended series of tutorials, but rather, the entire, short game. This game is begging for far more content than it has, and the small modding community has not picked up the slack. Such a disappointment.

1,481 produits enregistrés
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
7.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 11 aout 2019
Quadrilateral Cowboy is a great game. You have so many tools at your disposal, and the game itself is really quite immersive from the cyberdesk you can literally deploy anywhere, to the satisfying clacking of the keys as you plan out how you'll complete your objectives, because in most cases, you won't have a lot of time to act. You have a three second window to work with when it comes to disabling lasers or opening windows. I love the amount of tools you can work with, my personal favorite being the portable "weevil" drone you control via commands in the terminal, while your only method of FPV are two CRT monitors you'll deploy right next to your computer. It's these moments that are enjoyable. Plopping down your equipment wherever you please and tackling your objective from afar. I think I've seen a few comments comparing this game to Watch Dogs, and you know what? This is what I wish Watch Dogs was. But..Well..It's kind of just casual fodder, anyway.

It's such a satisfying feeling to breach a level, figure out the precise pattern to navigate through laser1 and laser 2, while having the door open with a delayed command. However, I share everyone else's sentiment that the game is too short, and there are tools you acquire that just don't feel like they're used enough. I'm conflicted about this, though. Because I don't want to pin this on Blendo Games and take points away from them, but on the other hand, it's a $20 game and it just needs a bit more meat on its bones. Maybe just a suggestion then, if ever they make a second game. Because this doesn't affect how I feel about Quadrilateral Cowboy. I think it's more of a testament of how much fun I had, and how great this game really is.

The level editor could've added a lot more replayability...Too bad no one uses it, though. I mean, there's like 8 items in total on the Steam workshop? Come on. A level editor is perfect for this kind of game. That is just unfair.
 
Starchild

My conclusion is that i can definitly recommend this.
if this is for you its worth every penny at full price!

Évaluation publiée le 31 juillet 2016
Wonderful if not a bit short (finished in just under 6 hrs). Great blending of the command-line / hacking genre wrapped in a first person puzzle game, and the whole thing is dripping with artistic style very reminiscent of that in Jazzpunk.

2,508 produits enregistrés

1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation amusante
0
Recommandé
11.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 27 juillet 2016
Upon finishing this game I can honestly say that this is the most refreshing puzzle game since Portal! Some may be turned off by the fact that this is a 5 hour game for 20 euros but you can tell a lot of love and dedication was poured into this project. By entering code into your laptop you hack doors and laser grids, control robots and gimbal turrets in order to steal classified information from a variety of places. For me this is the first game where it actually feels like you are hacking. Quadrilateral Cowboy even boasts a Dark Souls like message system where you can post post-it notes in the levels which your Steam friends can see. Highly recommended!

Recommandé
5.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 12 février 2019
Produit reçu gratuitement

ハッカー女子トリオの人生の物語。

Quadrilateral Cowboy 
Une capture d'écran de Quadrilateral Cowboy
Par : Funuke


同開発者の「Gravity Bone」「Thirty Flights of Loving」の後継作と言えるでしょう。
物語重視一直線だった前作と比較すると今作はゲームプレイの部分がかなり強化されています。
そして、ゲームをクリアした後には強烈な印象が残ります。

ゲームプレイはハッキングのミニゲームをよりそれっぽくしたといった感じで、基本的にキーボードを使ったコマンド入力で進行しますが難しいことはありません。ゲームの流れで必要なことは順々に教えてくれます。

Quadrilateral Cowboy 
Une capture d'écran de Quadrilateral Cowboy
Par : Funuke


しいて言えば、解法自体は至ってシンプルなので逆に複雑に考えすぎて余計なことをしてしまってた場面が多かったです。フレンド機能と連動したタイムアタック要素もありますが、基本的に解法は一つしかなく、最適解を考えるような内容でもないのでその辺はあまり機能してないようにも思えました。

まずはフリータイトルの「Gravity Bone」に触れてみて何か惹かれるものがあったらぜひ本作も遊んでみてください。

 
Funuke

This is one of those few unique game ideas with the dedication to pull through on it. Immersive Sim by low budget, original "coding" gameplay combined with the blissful cooled-down Blendo Games atmosphere and aesthetic known from Thirty Flights of Love (also fantastic, if only 15 minutes long; trust me). Especially recommended for anyone interested in IT even if you've never played a video game.

8/10

check my ratings on rateth.at to see if they align with yours (bc if they do you should buy this game)

5.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 27 aout 2016
Okay. The game's core is good. there's loads of interesting mecanics and there's really a LOT of fun stuff to do with what you have in hands.

Sadly, there isn't enough content. There's only 9 levels and doing them once is enough since there's ONE solution per "puzzle"

In less than 5 hours you can do the whole game.

A lot of mecanics are really underused, some even just show up for one tutorial and one level and are never heard from ever again.

The game is great. I don't think that it's worth 20€ though.
 
Naberius
1,869 produits enregistrés
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
4.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 1 aout 2016
After finishing Quadrilateral Cowboy I can firmly say that it is great!
Although the actual play time was pretty short the pacing made it feel much longer than it really was.
As with Blendo's previous games this one is just brimming with charisma and charm; there are lots of tiny nods to previous works and movies that influenced the game.

I couldn't help noticing that the game felt really influenced by the anime Cowboy Bebop (and I'm not just saying this cause of my name); Chung had previously said in an interview that the little red bullet boxes that appear in some of his games were taken from the show and it seems like quite a few more references and themes were taken from it. They both have a small band of misfits taking odd jobs and casually going to space. There is also the same mix of cultures in the enviroments that Bebop is full of; and they both have Cowboy in the title!


Spoilers from here!

The ending felt like it touched on a lot of the key themes from that show. It ends with you reminissing on the life of crime that you lived when younger; it seems like a happy ending but if you look carefully just before the final photgraph that triggers the end credits there are books on hospice care, and because you're the only person in the ending sequence it heavily implies that your partners in crime are probably now very ill or already dead; suggesting that all that fun that was had was only part of the past; in fact it kind of recontextualizes the entire game to from the perspective of older you looking back. In fact the leaderboards urging for a faster time after each heist suggest that you are looking back at the heists you completed during you life and thinking about how much better they could have been run.

The reason I think this theme of recognizing that all of that was back in the past is also inspired by Bebop is because that is literally the key themes of Bebop; every character in that show has something from their past that they are either too focused on or trying to run away from.

So maybe I'm just crazy and maybe obsessed with an anime, but considering Chung has mentioned that show as an inspiration to earlier works I think it is interesting to look into similarities.
 
RawHerring
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
5.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 26 juin 2019
A really interesting game that takes simple coding and mechanizes it into a whole game. It has the usual Bendo charm to it but fleshes it out more into a 3 to 5 hour experience rather than just their usual 30 or so minutes. I think the art style works for what it is, I played Gravity Bone and Thirty Flights of Loving before this and thought the style was already pretty good for it's 70s esque aesthetic, but it does feel weird to see certain elements that weren't in those two, such as the more cyberpunk elements, but I quickly got used to them. My favorite parts were the puzzles and how logical yet incredibly simple they could be once you figure it all out and understand the coding language for each of your tools, and looking at a guide after finishing the game seemed to give off the sense that there are multiple solutions to each puzzle, so that was pretty neat to figure out. However, this game isn't without its faults, I think the puzzles and in fact the entire game itself ends way too soon, where just as soon as you get to a point where things pick up, the game ends, and its a shame as I felt there was a little more you can do, though I still haven't tried out any mod levels so that might satiate my fix for that. One gameplay moment I really didn't enjoy was the level where you played as Lou and Maisy as it felt really pointless, as you do one quick puzzle with them and immediately gain both of their abilities after you finish it, and it makes me question why even keep it in the first place. The story itself is a bit lacking too as while it feels like you go through an entire arc and can understand what is happening by the time you finish, I personally felt there wasn't much beyond what you could figure out on your own, somewhat a facsimile of the game itself in a sense, however my complaints with the story can be considered a small complaint, as it really doesn't take much hold over the puzzles even once stakes are increased. Overall, a really good game for those who love puzzles and games with a unique style and personality.
 
I'm Not a Furry But...

Évaluation publiée le 29 octobre 2017
This game is in desperate need of play-testing.

After only having played it for 1hr, I've managed to break it in a number of ways... I'm not bosting, if anything I feel stupid because I just want to get past these things so I can see what else this game has to offer.

I've spent more time trying to figure out "what is the most predictable way to complete a level", than just doing what I want, and solving the puzzles along the way.
I've also had to completely re-start my "career" from scratch because I closed a door and it never reopened.

Look, it's a good idea... no, it's a great idea!... but I'm finding it hard to have fun.

edit: now I can't press [up] to select previous commands without them running, I've verified game files, there's something seriously wrong here, but I can't find any other negative reviews that say the same... I'm very confused, I think real-life is a better option right now.

Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
17.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 8 janvier 2017
Yes it's short and yes there's a bit of missed potential to flesh out what it's doing, but it's not like Quadrilateral Cowboy is RUINED for it. The "hacking" mechanic is so sick, and the gadgets and abilities QC throws at you along the way makes things consistently interesting. And it's all taught to you amazingly well. I loved the challenge in experimenting with the code while learning the timing imposed by the level design to become an electronic god. Trying to beat levels in the fastest time possible, using as few commands as possible, is so much fun, but the game is forgiving enough that you don't have to speed through if that's too difficult for you. The best concept for a puzzle game since Portal.

Kashadoo
415 produits enregistrés
0
3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
6.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 14 octobre 2020
Quadrilateral Cowboy is an idea which sounds good on paper, but in reality, doesn’t translate well to the video game format.

It has lots of cool ideas but doesn’t really know how to build upon them or assimilate them all into a unified whole. Instead, for the most part, they seem to be used in isolation from one another, which is a wasted opportunity and doesn’t really make for a satisfying experience. Then there’s the inherent problem that constantly typing commands is, you know… not exactly fun no matter how it’s presented! Especially so when you’re constantly referring back to your command list because you can’t possibly remember them all…

Ultimately, the real problem with the game is that the developers had a cool idea (i.e., heists and hacking) but no fun gameplay mechanic with which to accommodate it - the exact opposite of how good game design should be. It feels more like a learning tool quickly cobbled together by a programming teacher as a “fun” and interactive means for his students to learn. Ironically, though, the game doesn’t actually explain its mechanics very well at all, making learning quite difficult. There’s nothing wrong with a puzzle game being difficult because of its puzzles, but when it’s due to incompetent tutorials which leave the player unsure of how to use the many tools at their disposal, it becomes less forgivable.

Lastly, the game is also very buggy and glitchy; one of the worst games I’ve played for years in this regard, in fact.

So, quite a few negatives there. The game does have its moments, but these are few and far between and the lasting impression of Quadrilateral Cowboy is one of frustration and boredom.
 
vietnamvet
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
5.2 h en tout

I've never played anything like this game. It allows you to control the world using simple commands that it teaches you throughout the game. Amazing atmosphere and new concept. Never played anything else like it.

So far extremely fun. Once you get pasted the first few mission it really gets started. Lots of items to use. fun learning to write some simple code and learning how to time stuff out. 232 produits enregistrés
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
5.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 31 juillet 2016
Vidéo YouTube™: Baasvik Reviews- Quadrilateral Cowboy 
Vues : 525
Baasvik is back after a mental hiatus to bely you with a review on a hacking game from Blendo Games called Quadrilateral Cowboy. Typical self-deprecation and skits are here.


Sometimes you just want to sit in from of a pc while sitting in front of your PC. If you're an idiot like me, I'd bargain this is the game for you. Blendo is back with their masterful pacing and obtuse storytelling, and even now comes with a video game packed inside.

Inventive and creative, Quadrilateral Cowboy is a very good game. No single mechanic is ever exhausted and QC captures a feeling in a way most games can't. You'll walk away from Quadrilateral Cowboy feeling like a true hacker, even if all security systems in this universe are extremely rudimentary.

A few twists and turns here and there keep things fresh and make QC a must-play for fans of indie games.

Not without its flaws though, there are definitely plenty of engine issues with Quadrilateral Cowboy. I found myself clipping through environments, stuck in walls, and dealing with sloppy transitions regularly. An overall clunky interface can also be a bear on the experience.

Luckily its flaws don't hold it back too much and there's plenty here to like.
 
Baasvik

Recommandé
12.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 31 décembre 2017
A game with class. Extreme class.

Beautiful environments, clear spatial representation, a fusion of aesthetic eye candy and interactive player mechanics. The heists and gadgets are accessible and exciting, the tools are funcitonal, programmable, and tactically deployed with ease. You will enjoy using the tools to gain access to the building's systems and loot, loot loot.

The game certainly delivers on those promises. But if you really take the time to poke around and use all your senses, you will also find a subtle and understated story about 3 living characters that will touch you. It is there if you open your eyes. You will be guided by beautiful and interactive artwork, flavorful yet minimalistic text snippets, and an extremely tasteful score of classic music.

Its gameplay will definitely not let you down, but if your measurement is "Can games be art?" this one gets a 10/10.
 
Fridge Lord

Évaluation publiée le 3 novembre 2017
Es bonito. Es divertido. Es gracioso. Y es una obra que se ve muy personal. Al principio parece difícil, pero ♥♥♥ el tiempo te acostumbras a todos los controles y realmente sienta genial cuando consigues una combinación de comandos ♥♥♥ el que pasar un nivel.

A la hora de la dificultad pasa ♥♥♥ Portal, tiene una curva muy bien hecha. Nunca resulta aburrido, o monótono, ya que cada poco el juego añade una mecánica más.

No tengais porque veais el juego y penseis que es difícil. Jugadlo, pasad un buen rato, y si quereis más descargaros algunos de los montones de mods que hay.


Estaría guay que fuera más largo. O que tuviera un editor de mapas fácil de usar para que cualquiera puediera hacer y subir misiones.

191 produits enregistrés

8 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
2.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 9 novembre 2018
I hated to thumb down this game because it is really good 'IF' you like that sort of thing. Let me explain:
It is listed as a puzzle game but it is more of an Arcade Game. You know the kind, you have to do things 'Over and Over' until you jump at the exact second, or hide from something, a timer running, etc. etc. I hate these kind of games (They are the type that were originally designed to keep you pumping quarters into a Video Arcade Machine.
I like just plain Puzzle Games like the ones at miller world inc that just present you with a puzzle and you then just have to figure out the answer. A true puzzle game shouldn't require you to learn new keystrokes, time jumps, run fast, hide, guess what you are supposed to do next. Those types of games just try and get you to figure out what the programmer wanted you to do, in what order, how fast or slow, etc. They are not true puzzles but more like idiot training like you would do your dog. With a true puzzle, once you realize the answer you would just do it (Not have to figure out HOW the programmer wanted you to do it...with the jump to exact location, run faster, etc. etc. like I explained above.
Of course, if you like that sort of frantic pressure, you may Love Quadrilateral Cowboy.
The thing that threw me was that the game starts off as a true puzzle game and then slowly meta-morphs into the arcade type.

Évaluation publiée le 6 juillet 2021
I had been looking forward to playing this game for a long time. Biding my time and waiting for a discount greater than 50% but eventually I caved in and picked it up at half of. It was sitting at 100% positive reviews at the time so I figured I couldn't go too far wrong.

It's not terrible but it feels unfinished. Some parts are frustrating like moving vaults especially when multiple launchers are involved but that is a relatively minor gripe. My main complaint is that there isn't enough to justify in being good. When it finally feels like the next level might be challenging, it's over. It was so unsatisfying how little content there was. I think there are around 10 missions but half of those felt like they were tutorial missions and none of them felt particularly meaty.

tldr: I was underwhelmed if that's a word

Évaluation publiée le 2 octobre 2016
It started out pretty cool with a nice atmosphere and fun first mission. Every chapter is basically an introduction to one new mechanic. But unfortunately the missions are pretty much based solely on that single mechanic. They don't build on top one another until the very last mission, which came way too quickly.

There's also a couple chapters in the middle of the game where you don't even use your computer at all. That's the main draw to the game and then they completely get rid of it!

Overall I would not recommend it, not at its current price point (I paid 22CAD).
 
WakaLaka
1
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
5.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 20 décembre 2021
This game is a VERY tentative recommend. If you're an avid shell scripter, get it on sale.

The core gameplay loop is genius. You have a computer that you can use to hack various devices in the level, and you have to execute a heist in a Payday-esque fashion. The problem is that you can quite easily complete the entire game without even touching the best parts, and the interface almost hides it from you. You can breeze through the game just typing commands one by one, but the most fun comes from optimising your runs.

The hacking puzzles aren't "solve the maze and unlock the door!" but are, truly, hacking puzzles. You've already taken advantage of your target's poor security practices, you're already in. Your job isn't to solve soup cans, but to figure out what set of inputs the devices need to do what you want, and then... do your job.

But the best part comes when you pre-program the inputs. Instead of walking up to the door, taking out your laptop, typing out the command... Save your time and just, write a script that opens up all the doors you care about at specific times. The game provides the ability to create batch files in the first level and just... never tells you! It's wild!

And each element unlocked gives way to new interesting programming problems. The Weevil is a little robot that you can pilot by typing commands, one by one. And you can beat the entire section doing that. Or, you could program it to follow a specific set of steps...

The Esquire Deck is a beautifully powerful piece of simulated 80's tech, and yet the game doesn't encourage you to make full use of it in any way. As a card-carrying Linux user, writing up scripts to do useful tasks is something I find incredibly fun. It's tragic how underutilised the thing is, given how many hidden features it has. Did you know you can change the terminal colours just for fun?

In short: as a piece of art and proof of concept, this game is delightful. As a complete experience, it's severely lacking. The levels are simple and in no way point to the best parts of the gameplay, sometimes even discouraging it (through levels that require careful timing of hitting the "run command" key, or unpredictable physics weirdness). I'd welcome another game in this genre. As a programmer, maybe i'd even make one. The "execute, restart, optimise" gameplay loop is just *that* engaging.
 
Dther

Évaluation publiée le 9 octobre 2016
Maybe the best game ever!
(yes I'm serious about this)

It's the game kids in the 80ies dreamed about but back then wasn't really possible. The whole atmosphere, the exploration, the puzzles, the characters, the visuals, the story, the weirdness... everything is perfect and fitting.

And yes the game is rather short but the whole gameplay doesn't repeat anything unnecessarily. Every new heist has a unique refreshing approach.

For me only one thing I didn't like that much was the music but I guess that's just my taste since it was still kinda fitting. Also you are given the possibility to turn it off anyway.

(Finally, it runs superb on Linux/SteamOS)

Quadrilateral Cowboy scratches a very specific itch I didn't know I had. It's a fantastic stealth/puzzle game that makes me feel like a movie level hacker. Just the sounds of typing this out brings me back my favorite moments in the game. That's what I call immersion.

Highly recommended for those looking for a more against the grain experience with strong, sold game mechanics.

Recommandé
7.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 22 aout 2016
Here is a list of ways I can describe this game, in relation to other games:
  • Like Blendo Games' other offerings, but with more structure
  • Like Portal, but with more planning and more complex puzzles
  • Like Digital: A Love Story, but hacking the real world instead of the Gibson
If the idea of keying up a batch script to disable an array of lasers in perfect sequence, or using a remote turret to hit a button through a grate in the ceiling, or catapulting yourself from building to building on blasts of air appeals to you, buy this game. If the idea of carefully planning your escape, then executing it flawessly with a single command appeals to you, buy this game.

If you read all this, and you still have no idea what's going on, buy it anyway, and see what you think. If you don't like it, you can always return it.

MPO
422 produits enregistrés

Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
6.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 5 septembre 2017
I enjoyed Quadrilateral Cowboy a lot. The aesthetic was great and the missions were fun.

Some hacking games give you a point-and-click GUI. Those seem simplistic to me. Some hacking games bog you down in a pure command line. Those feel like work. I think that this game was very well balanced in that respect.

I like to approach games like this without knowing anything about them because they're such a joy to discover as you go.
That said, some specifics on what the game is about if you don't mind more details: Essentially, you pull off a series of heists and you have various little programmable gadgets to help you do so. Sometimes there are time limits. Sometimes you are working in parallel with yourself. In the end, each mission felt very satisfying.

And a couple of things to help you enjoy the game and not get stuck like I did exactly once:
If you're into exploration, I highly recommend reading everything with text on it. There were some wine bottles with clever labels in the very first intro mission, and those got me started enjoying the fine print during the rest of the game.

I had a lovely time and I can already think of several friends that I know will enjoy it as well.
 
adeilt
1,781 produits enregistrés
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
5.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 24 novembre 2017
In short: You looking at this game? Crack your knuckles and bust out your cosset player and Buy it. You wont regret it!!

This game stands out from the crowd. Its a unique game mechanic which might be a little dawnting for some, its a breath of fresh air.. Starting off with simple commands to strings of code.. Ok maybe not strings since its limited to 3 commands at a time but still.... Whilst short, at only around 5.5 hrs. Its well worth the money. THe air style my deter some folks with its very basic blocky vector art... Even so i do enjoy it.

The ONLY Negitive i have about since game is towards the ending.... WTF was that all about? I won't spoil anything (and no its nothing game breaking or something that should stray you away from this game) but really? A sudden change of gameplay was a little unexpected.. Granted its only for a couple of missions but still... Kinda broke the flow a little.

Oh and story is a non excistant (kinda like my spelling!) We're just dropped into the game and off we go.. All we know is that we're friends from School days and we hack stuff for money. Not a deal breaker but a little clarification would have been nice.

Over all its a lovely little game. And HIGHLY Reccomend you try it for your self :)
 
Smed
0
16 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
2.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 31 juillet 2016
Produit reçu gratuitement

I really want to like this game. The theme and the asthetic is great (I'm a big fan of oldschool/retro cyberpunk and sci-fi) and there is a lot of detail to be found. The mechanics seem very interesting (I'm also a fan of games that use a command line interface as one of the primary input methods) and are quite diverse. You have a little hacking device you can plug into datajacks, a cyberdeck (or should I call it a suitecase deck?) which allows you to hack doors and stuff, a little robot you can give commands to and a bunch of other stuff.
The main problem I have with the game is: It is not a puzzle game. If I look at those mechanics I think "puzzle game!" immediately. But it's not. The challenge of the game is not coming from "solving" any logical puzzles. Those are all trivial and very straight forward. Instead you are supposed to complete the different levels as quickly as possible to compete on a leaderboard.
So is it a good time attack/speedrun game? I don't think so. Because while the mechanics are interesting and diverse, controling them feels very cluncy (it almost feels like that is on purpose) and are not very fun to use after you get past the "oh! shiny command line interface!" hype.

I think this game would have benefitted greatly by being a puzzle game with interesting puzzle design. I'm very sad it is not.

Gameplay and in depth discussion:
Vidéo YouTube™: What is Quadrilateral Cowboy? - by th_pion 
Vues : 339
Quadrilateral Cowboy is a Retro-Cyberpunk First-Person Hacking Time-Attack Game! Steam: http://bit.ly/2amsVr2 This video was produced with a free review copy provided by the developer.

Toilet Slave Tournament
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
12.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 4 janvier 2020
It's a shame it took me so long to buy this game, it's exactly my kind of game! I haven't even finished it yet but I want to recommend it already. I guess it took me a while because it advertises itself as a hacking game, which in games means "play stupid mini games in terminal windows". It's just not a very informative classification.

What this is in fact is a unique game that I'll just call a heist planner game. While stealth games focus on, well, stealth and improvisation -- the execution part of a heist -- this one focus on the planning aspect of it. This counterpoint with stealth games is pretty weak though, it still plays like a stealth game without sneaking. You have full knowledge of the place, you can noclip and fly around, and complete the heist in the simulator. It's all about navigating the environment and using your computer to open doors, turn off lasers, control turrets etc. You can concatenate commands to perform complex actions. Some actions are timed, like for example, some door that triggers an alarm after 3 seconds opened.

Although I am having a great time with this game, it is a game with a very limited audience and rough around the edges, so I am finding the price tag a bit high. As I said, I am enjoying it so to me it's worth it, but it's a risky acquisition.

I hope there are user made levels because this game would benefit tremendously from that. I know there are mods, from quickly looking over the forums.

4 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile

Non recommandé
2.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 27 janvier 2017
Initially felt very promising, but everything after the intro fell flat.

♥♥♥♥:
No overarching story or subplots to follow, only out-of-place recreation sequences attempting to add depth to characters. Simplistic puzzles where the main mechanic appears to be speed running, pivoting around the gadget-of-the-day. No real depth to puzzles requiring a multitude of techniques to overcome, or replayability via trying different approaches. Perhaps most disappointing was the hacking element, which was really more of hacking theatre. Imagine driving a controller with command line inputs and that's the gist of it.

Pros:
A minimalistic art style paired with a music theme I highly enjoyed. Many of the stability issues seem to have been addressed.

Recommendations:
Hope for a writer & level designer + more time I suppose. With that, if you like feeling like a hacker and enjoy speedrunning, look for this on sale. If you're looking for good puzzle or coding elements keep moving.

Évaluation publiée le 25 juillet 2016
I just finished playing the first few missions of this game, and I am pretty impressed. The main aim of the game is to infiltrate buildings by using a laptop to hack your way in. Very user-friendly, teaches you the mechanics step-by-step. Potential replayability, with workshop compatibility.

_Pros_
-Makes you feel like a hacker
-Cool retro cyberpunk feel
-Intense. challenging, and fast-paced puzzles
-Cool mechanics

_Cons_
-Lack of atmosphere while outside
-Thats all I could think of, I haven't run into any bugs yet :)

So far, i give this game a 7/10
I HAVE NOT COMPLETED THE GAME, NOR AM I CLOSE TO BEATING THE GAME. THIS REVIEW IS MY FIRST IMPRESSION AND WILL BE UPDATED UPON COMPLETION.

Accidently Reviewed

I wanted to write this review to thank Blendo Games for another masterpiece. I am in love. I *almost* don't want to finish the game, because I fear I'll still want more. Thank you guys for all the cheeky references to your other games, (All of which I have played and thoroughly enjoyed) the trophys and other easter eggs were a neat find. This time around, you have really outdone yourselves, this game plays like, and feels like and instant classic that I'll still be talking about and showing 10 years from now, just like Zombie Atom Smasher, Air Forte, and Flotilla. I was a bit skeptical on the price at first, but decieded you guys have earned it if not for this game then for all the others, but when I played it I felt like my money was more than well spent.
I know this is less a review and more a plain ass kissing, but these guys sh*t pure gold, every time without fail, so I'd be glad to get some on my lips just to thank them for all the experiences.

2.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 5 janvier 2021
I love the actual gameplay, but at an aesthetic level this game is viscerally unpleasant to play. The player sound effects (even the non-damage ones) are stomach-churning gasps. The harsh lighting makes it very difficult to understand the level geometry (they have those zoom eyes, but they can't do some kind of optical amplification/exposure compensation?) and the dynamic lighting elements feel like something tacked on because it's high-tech not because it makes the experience better (it actually makes it worse).
 
AJMansfield
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
9.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 4 octobre 2016
DISCLAIMER: This is a first impressions review, and NOT a full review, if you want a full review, then please read better reviews then mine

Quadrilateral Cowboy is a game developed by Blendo Games. A romantic look into 90's tech and the glamor of hacking; the game is about learning skills to pull off a good heist. You get equipment in game that allows you to accomplish new and different things, furthering your ability to get creative and solve puzzles in mutliple ways

Most of these new abilities manifest as commands issued through your deck, which is a little hacking computer that you set up somewhere within each scenario to connect into framework technology that controls things like grates, doors, vents, and other accesible spaces

Blendo Games have a knack for storytelling and scene creation that is dazzling and clever. This game made me feel like kind of a badass on the technical front. Story wise, I found it to be emotionally impactful and rewarding!

Quadrilateral Cowboy is the newest and most enjoyable Blendo Games' game I've played so far!

RECOMMENDED :)
 
ThePCGamer
1,934 produits enregistrés
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
6.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 22 novembre 2018
Some intersting ideas but feels more like a proof of concept than an actual game to be honest. You are given tools in a most psychedelic way, then presented with a scenario in which that tool is used, then you move on to the next "level". Unfortunately, at the "Repulse Bay Impound Lot" level the gameplay changes completely, from simple problem solving to a timed trial-and-error thing where you have to change back and forth between characters in a way that made zero sense to me. Overall, the game is thick with WTF is going ons and very little else.

Maybe if these tools were given in a more sandboxey game world where the player could explore, learn and discover his way through gradually opening up a world at their own pace this game would appeal to me more. Would not recommend unless it's on sale and you have an interest in unconventional game design.

Évaluation publiée le 29 octobre 2017
Good level design overall, but you will hardly be stuck more than 30s. Don't come to QC for a puzzle game but rather for a cocktail of moderately difficult platform/reflexion. I had a good time on that game.

I unfortunately can't recommend that game due to a VERY excessive price (~20€) for such a short experience (<4h to complete). I got it for ~10€ during the Halloween 2017 sales and still think it's a bit overpriced. If you have the chance to grab it for around 7€, then you would have a good deal :)

I also would like to precise I was expecting that game for such a long time, so much I was regularly visiting the webpage to check the release date since it was up.
 
MMz
758 produits enregistrés
0
3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
17.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 14 octobre 2016
It is a very entertaining puzzle game. While it is not a strict "terminal game" you do use a command line to enter text commands throughout the game. I really wish I could recommend it, but with the non-stop issues I've been having, I can't, in good faith, do it.

My only complaints are with the bugs I have run into while playing it. After running it for a couple of hours, the game will spontaneously lock up. Sometimes when I load the game it will load into a 640x480 window and freeze. And sometimes when I play, I am not able to cycle back through the keyboard commands without it also adding a carriage return. (IE, if my last command was "test" I should be able to hit the up arrow to get the "test" command line to appear in my current field--however, while it does bring up the "test" command it effectively hits <ENTER> executing the command by itself). Most of the time I can just cycle through all of my previous commands with no issues, but once this started happening, I have not been able to stop it from happening. I have posted these issues in the support forum, but have not received a single response.

I'm sure it will all be patched and working in a few months and by then I can revisit it and (hopefully) change my recommendation.

0B51DIAN
103 produits enregistrés
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
3.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 19 octobre 2023
A wonderful adventure game where you plan heists using a computer and programmable gadgets set in a retro-future 70s/80s world. Blendo excels at intricate and tactile animations and just the way things like your autogun unfolds from its suitcase triggers every pleasure nerve receptor. Actual gameplay involves simplified text input, telling your remote controlled robot to walk 10 paces, wait 3 seconds, and open a door for you.

Unfortunately Quadrilateral Cowboy is hindered by its small scope. Imagining a Thief-like clockwork puzzle game where you have access to a full range of tools to accomplish the goal how you want is in the realm of possibility but not realistically with one person. It remains up there with Gunpoint as a game that punches above its weight class, it's fun to imagine how much further they could've pushed the concept, but both games are good for what they are provided you engage them on their terms.
 
That Guy
3,754 produits enregistrés
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
5.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 14 octobre 2023
This game is a masterpiece in its own right. Although it is quite short (it's about 3-4 hours long) and the graphics won't blow you away in any sense of the word, the game is OOZING atmosphere at every narrative and gameplay corner. Despite Quadrilateral Cowboy not entertaining the vibrantly extremist aesthetic, the game is very much cyberpunk. You play a heist artist hacker (basically a netrunner or cyberjockey) who in virtual reality plans the perfect heist to then execute it once the player solved the puzzle of how to make the heist come to fruition. In the beginning you have only your cyberdeck with which you can hack infrastructure of the buildings you're entering, but with each successfully pulled off heist your repertoire of toys and gimmicks grows. Each time you finsish a chapter you get rewarded with either a new gadget, a bit of fun story, or both. I seriously cannot recommend it enough. Don't let the 20€ price tag scare you away, this game has infinite replayability and is well worth the 20

Soobinism
1,118 produits enregistrés
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
2.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 11 septembre 2023
Very short. Feels like an immersive sim, but most levels have an extremely linear solution. I love any command line interface hacking game (See Uplink) and this one had some really neat ideas. The story and ending was touching, but so minimalist it's hard to walk away from this feeling complete. I can tell you this games story in one sentence without using the worlds "because", "suddenly", "but", or anything that actually adds some tension.

The Blendo games catalog is very cute, and great for people who want a short, fun, very indie experience. This is the only one out of the "Citizen Abel" series that actually has some tangible gameplay. If you don't like Gravity Bone and Thirty Flights of Loving, you won't like anything but gameplay here, as it's pretty in line with those.

If you want a hacking game, go play Uplink first. If you want that quirky style this game has, it's not a bad romp.
 
Trev
657 produits enregistrés
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
7.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 22 aout 2023
The idea of a retrofuturistic techno-heist using a laptop to hack laser grids in real time is fun. Using simplistic function calls on your suitcase laptop to do things like open doors, direct a little drone, or fire a remote-controlled sniper rifle (beanbags, no violence here) makes for a novel little puzzler.

However, my opinion is that the stages are just too short, and the game itself has very few stages where you really get to build up on your skills. Each stage introduces one new mechanic, and only the last one has a "use what you've learned" feeling to it with multiple challenges to overcome. The story and setting are... let's go with "minimalist," though the Blender Games aesthetic pulls a lot of weight here.

TL;DR: I've completed it in less than 10 hours, and that was with a lot of purposeful screwing around to look at all the little details in the world. I might give it another go with the developer commentary, but I've very much wrung this game dry and don't plan to return to it in the future. It's worth playing if you have the time and the inclination.

Qube
485 produits enregistrés
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
19.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 25 aout 2023
I think this game is really interesting. After donating to an itch.io campaign, I received access to Quadrilateral Cowboy and many other games. This game stuck out to me. So, I bought and downloaded the game on Steam to see what it felt like to fully play it.

The main goal of this game is to perform heists on various places, such as banks, houses, space elevators, etc. usually to retrieve an item like a vault, photograph a contract and more. You get a variety of tools to do this, namely your Deck; a portable PC capable of controlling grates, doors, lasers and more. You also use the Deck to make use of your other items, like a suitcase with a built-in gun or a little robot named Nell who can move and connect to USB ports (named datajacks). As you progress through the game, you unlock more tools like launch pads and a magnet for Nell, as well as upgrades to your character like better jumping and speed. There's around 10 heisty-type levels with 8 additional story levels to go through. I think this game is quite replayable as there are many ways to complete a heist, and you usually get 3 missions in 1 heist, so there's a lot of content.

My main problems with the game are minimal. It's clear there's some sort of lore or story to find, as there are levels where you pick up certain characters from their houses and usually have people around you in your office / compound as you complete missions. But the game never really tells you what any of this means. I'm not a big story person so I don't really mind as much, but I just wish it was expanded on a bit more. I want to know who these people are.

Concepts and ideas the game presents typically get underused or skipped over quite quickly. For example, midway through the game you move from your office to a blimp / ship thing, and the game introduces the ability to play as three different characters, someone who can only noclip to scope out missions, an engineer who can open grates and press buttons and a faster character who can actually complete missions and run quickly. This is used for about three levels before going back to the original format of just one character. It's just strange to me.

There are also many glitches in the game, like items disappearing or levels softlocking if you lose your Deck, but this engine DOES run on an old engine so it is forgivable. The most you'll have to do is restart your game if this happens.

However, most levels can be entirely skipped by grabbing your deck, putting it in the air, quickly letting go and then using the deck, then stashing it in your inventory before it hits the ground. This allows you to clip into the ground and basically skip most of the puzzles in the game. This also works in literally every level as well. With this glitch, levels that may take you 2+ minutes take 20 seconds.

Despite my small issues, I really did enjoy the game. It has a really unique art style and tons of tools to play around with. Even though I finished the game, I still find myself coming back to it, trying to speed run each of the levels. While it may not be everyone's game, I would definitely still give it at least one play through. There is something really special about Quadrilateral Cowboy.
 
JACK ★
243 produits enregistrés
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
14.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 31 juillet 2023
из сериала "Доктор Хаус" a écrit :
— Ключ был под ковриком. — Нет там никакого ключа! — Точно! Придется тебе окно заменить...

Blendo Games — американская независимая компания по разработке видео игр, расположенная в Калвер-Сити, Калифорния. Компания в основном является инициативой одного человека (Брендона Чанга) и специализируется на одиночных видео играх различного жанра.
Quadrilateral Cowboy это третья, но уже более полноценная часть из ретро-шпионской серии, в которую вошли короткие новеллы "Gravity Bone" и "Thirty Flights of Loving".

СЮЖЕТ
Действие происходит в 1980х. Трое высокотехнологичных авантюриста решают собрать команду с целью предотвращения планов крупных корпораций по установлению мирового господства. Команде предстоит выполнять различные миссии начиная с похищения документов и заканчивая взломом сложных технических систем.

ГЕЙМПЛЕЙ
Игра ведется от первого лица. Главный герой действует как хакер, использующий первоклассный хакерский компьютер, оснащенная модемом 56,6 КБ и ошеломляющей оперативной памятью 256 КБ. Действие хакера по подготовке к успешному выполнению миссий, происходит в каркасно-сетчатом виртуальном мире, в котором разрабатывается симуляция последовательности действий остальных членов команды. К слову у каждого члена команды имеется свой набор способностей, один из персонажей умело пользуется пилой для взлома дверей, а другой может карабкаться и быстро перемещаться по уровням миссий. Когда кто-то из команды сталкивается с запертыми дверями, камерами и другими элементами безопасности, в дело вступает хакер, который должен создать программу (а по сути написать цепочку команд), набрав ее в виде кода на своей физической клавиатуре, которая манипулирует функциями безопасности, не поднимая сигнала тревоги. По сути работа хакера заключается во взаимодействии с окружением и обозначение "хакер", тут служит как сценическая роль участника действий. Писать сложный код в виде многоуровневых конструкций игроку не придётся, в игре есть командная панель со списком пояснений к каждой, помимо этого перед началом каждой миссии игроку предлагается пройти краткий обучающий урок в котором подробно описывается последовательность действий каждой команды или работы приспособления. Говоря о сложности в процессе прохождения, то можно отметить только добавляющиеся приспособления к которым нужно привыкнуть в процессе игры. В остальном игровой процесс сопровождается всяческими подсказками и руководствами к действию, поэтому проходить её легко и непринуждённо.

ИТОГ
Данная игра-головоломка похожа на большой учебник знакомящий игрока с основными механиками действий игры. Основная идея заключалась в мастерской уровней, которую может освоить каждый, кто прошёл игру до конца. Сложность заключается только в непопулярности данного жанра.
Если вам нравятся гаджеты из 80х, пикселная графика, футуристичные киберпанк миры, кражи в стиле "миссия невыполнима", то эта игра определенно вам понравится.

Fun little hacking/infiltrating game. Use gadgets at your disposal and your hacking deck to infiltrate, acquire the target, and escape. Neat story to go along with it. Well paced progression with the gadgets that you acquire and the later missions require using multiple gadgets and gained hacking knowledge to solve.

8/10, about 5 to 6 hours in length.

Unlike some other games by this developer, it's more of a straight up puzzle game. Also, while you do use a computer and enter commands, it's not really a programming game. It's pretty short (6 hours in my first playthrough), but what's there is polished. New mechanics are introduced at a solid pace and I never felt like I was getting bored with it. I appreciated it not padding things out or dragging on.

Évaluation publiée le 1 décembre 2022
Chunky, tactile heist game for people who remember MS DOS and dial up modems. Maybe it's because I had severe insomnia last night and I've been up since 4am finishing the game and I'm very tired but I found the ending surprisingly emotional. What Blendo Games does extremely well (and what makes up for the arguably too short running time) is offering brief snapshots of its characters lives and allowing us to fill in the details.

走火入死
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
4.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 12 aout 2022
Steam Deck

Runs Fabulously on the Steam Deck with no issues. I didn't need Proton, because there is a native Linux executable available.

However, the game is VERY keyboard heavy. You're going to be using the "deck"/terminal during the heists/puzzles to enter commands. This will require a lot of typing and pressing up-arrow/down-arrow on your terminal history-list to edit commands and the Steam Deck... doesn't have a keyboard available outside of a virtual keyboard which is very slow to type on.

Can you do it? Absolutely. Do I recommend it? Not unless you attach a Bluetooth Keyboard or a USB Keyboard via a "Dock" for the Deck to run it that way.

(Also the default controller bindings don't have a crouch-button which is listed as Left CTRL on keyboards, BTW. Something you'd have to rebind in the Steam Controller Configurations)

It's a unique puzzler. Pretty fun to see a "hacking/heist" game use the keyboard and terminal commands (even if not fully accurate) to run commands and plan moves through the missions/puzzles.

Unfortunately, there's a few issues with the game: There is no subtitles/captions available for the "between missions" moments, so the artsy-fartsy story, is... missing for me. Beyond that, there are numerous bugs that have been reported (I, however, didn't run into any beyond a graphical rendering bug where the camera/CCTV's display would be seen in the maps areas at times, weirdly) to where some folks may/may not be able to finish the game.

If you can get it on sale, I recommend it. It's good fun, if a little "trial-error"-y with the "oh you caused an alert, time to die" system of it (due to the "start-stop" of having to enter commands to go through rooms that get locked or not).

I'm not sure if the developers/Blendo Games are still around, but hopefully there is someone that takes the ideas of it and runs with it in a better/more polished way in the future.

(Also it apparently runs on the Doom 3 engine, so most PC's past like... 2005 should be able to run the title swimmingly.)

It is worth every penny you will spend to purchase it. Support these developers so they can keep making brilliant small games like this.

Recommandé
8.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 28 juillet 2022
我通关了，这个游戏真的是让我又生气又快乐，在你打代码的时候，突然打错不执行的时候，我焦头烂额，但是在好不容易通关的时候，我欣喜万分，这个游戏的歌曲特别好听，噔噔——噔，充满年代感的音乐，在紧张敲代码中，给我带来一丝舒缓，这个游戏代入感很深，就感觉身临其境，玩着玩着，诶呦，黑天了，哈哈哈哈，沃特被推荐这款游戏，你别看我七个小时就通关了，但是这个游戏还是恨带感好玩的，一定要买，不买我就 RUA！（调皮）

最后一关攻略：太空站的，这关并不难，只要心态放平，肯定能过去，只是有点复杂，在通道的时候，一定要将小机器人放正，然后weever blink 1 datajack 0;datajack 1;jump;wait(1);datajack 0;datajack 1;stand;turn -180;这个代码肯定能帮到你，这个代码是黑掉你这边的接口的然后让小机器人跳到那边黑掉，一眨眼，就可以过去红外线长廊了，回来时，不要忘记，（这个和上面代码要敲到一起）blink 2 ~~然后后面和上面一样，只不过眨一下两下眼睛的代码罢了，最后到上面别忘了换一个新的氧气罩，然后到上面直接 exit 关掉这个枪的代码，然后打开 gate2 3 秒就可以了，下面开之后，把小机器人放到吹气口那 exit 然后weever datajack确认，出现一堆字母后，继续datajack 0 你要拿的东西就打开了，你一拿，换个氧气（对面墙上有）然后下去到紫色小块块那就可以了，你的游戏就通关了，之后会有很多回忆的事，（别忘了截屏）希望可以帮到你，若有不详细可以留言，我告诉你全部的！

Disunito
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
4.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 11 avril 2022
I've played everything Blendo released, and when this came out in 2016 I was excited to see what new weird and charming thing the author had in store for me. I played 23 minutes, nodded a bit and went "maybe later". It wasn't really what i was hoping for - sure it's a puzzle game, but I was imagining needing a lot more programming. Nothing crazy, but more than just a couple "do x; wait(1); do y; wait(2);" sequences.

After not thinking twice about it for 6 years, I reinstalled on a whim and tried it again. Maybe it's my age, maybe i just wanted to play something by this author, but something about it grabbed me and held on for the 3-4 hour runtime. In it I found the same weird and charming aesthetic only Blendo seems to pull off, a world that feels surprisingly physical for being so digital (thanks to all the easings and small animations) and a puzzle game that's still extremely linear, but with more fun ideas than I'd expected.

That's really the rub of this game, you don't really get much of a chance to play with what you've acquired. An item is introduced, you do a sequence of training missions (which are fun), and then you move to the next item. There's an innovative but boring section (the multi-sim) which introduces several items that are really only for style (not helping you to do anything you couldn't already do). Then, finally, you get one mission that feels like you're really getting going. Insert a bittersweet end sequence, roll credits.

It's still worth playing. But it will leave you wanting a little more.
 
K!netic

Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile

Defeygs
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
17.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 22 mars 2022
One of the most original and creative hacking and coding games in the market, it's style and esthetic feels so nice and fresh, this game singlehandedly turned casette futurism into my favorite aesthetic, just the old style of computers and hacking where you'd get computer programs in casette tapes, where your systems where just 128kb as an upgrade it's just so... charming. Though keep present this game is short, you could finish it when you arrive at the doctor's office waiting for him to call you, yet changing the way you play, taking different approaches is always nice. Just one thing, when you get the sniper rife, you can adjust the angle of view by decimal values, meaning zero, then coma, then a number for when one side or the other won't cut it.

It also has levels you can download from the community page but in my experience the launching/boosting fans tends to crash the game after one or two runs and the better games were all made by the dev himself. Overall a decent experience.
